CHAPTER 2  
Physiological and pathological  
cardiac adaptations to physical  
exercise  
Antonello D’Andreaa,b, Francesco Gambardellac,  
and Eugenio Picanod  
aUnit of Cardiology and Intensive Coronary Care,“Umberto I” Hospital, Nocera Inferiore, Italy  
bDivision of Cardiology, Department ofTranslational Medical Sciences, University of Campania “Luigi  
Vanvitelli”, Monaldi Hospital, Naples, Italy  
cPublic Health Deparment, University of Naples Federico II, Naples, Italy  
dInstitute of Clinical Physiology, Italian National Research Council, Pisa, Italy  
1 Introduction  
The cardiovascular system has a great capacity to adapt to changes in the he-  
modynamic conditions of the body.This happens clearly in various patholog-  
ical conditions, which can expose the heart to different overload conditions  
that can adaptations various adaptation.A volume overload, such as in aortic  
or mitral insufficiency, will predominantly result in a change in ventricular  
internal diameters, while a pressure overload, such as in aortic stenosis, will  
mainly cause an increase in the thickness of the walls of the heart. Similarly,  
sports activity is also associated with variations in the overall hemodynamic  
state, resulting in changes in the conditions in which the heart works.  
Other than the type of sports activity, environmental conditions are  
also one of the main determinants of adaptive cardiovascular responses.The  
same physical effort carried out under different conditions of atmospheric  
pressure, humidity, and temperature will require and involve a different be-  
havior of the cardiovascular system. Similarly, exogenous substances taken  
by the athlete for different reasons can modify the cardiovascular response  
and therefore the physical performance, with possible serious health risks  
associated, especially if frequently used.  
2 Physiological modification of the heart  
with physical exercise  
The role of physical activity in determining cardiovascular “well-being”  
has been the subject of increasing attention in the last decades. Since  
Athlete’s Heart  
Copyright © 2023 Elsevier Inc.  
All rights reserved.  
https://doi.org/10.1016/B978-0-323-95221-7.00001-X  
15  
16  
Athlete’s heart  
the 1960s, a large number of reports and studies have investigated what  
consequences on the human organism, and specifically on the heart,  
could derive from different types and different intensities of physical  
exercise carried out regularly. The increased muscular effort resulting  
from physical activity is at the basis of the corresponding increase in the  
performance of the cardiovascular system, responsible for the transport  
of oxygen and energy substrates to the muscles themselves.This occurs  
through transitional functional adjustments that depend on the environ-  
mental conditions in which the exercise takes place, other than the type  
and intensity of the exercise itself. Such modifications of cardiovascular  
performance can occur both in trained and sedentary subjects.Their per-  
sistence in athletes is dependent on various factors, such as the physio-  
logical characteristics of the subject, largely genetically determined, the  
age and duration of the activity, and its type and intensity.The perfect ef-  
ficiency of the cardiovascular system is therefore crucial for physical per-  
formance.The greater supply of oxygen to the muscles is ensured by (1)  
an increase in district blood flow that can reach the active muscle values  
even 20–25 times greater than the value at rest (3–75mL× 100g× min)  
and (2) increased oxygen extraction from the blood, demonstrated by the  
increased arteriovenous difference of O2 that can go from 5mL× 100mL  
of blood at rest to 17–18mL× 100mL in the athlete [1,2].The increase  
of blood flow to the muscles takes place thanks to central mechanisms  
implemented by the heart, and peripheral mechanisms implemented by  
the district circulation (Table 1).  
Table 1 Cardiovascular adaptations to physical activity.  
Central  
adaptations  
Peripheral  
adaptations  
↑ CO  
↑↑ HR  
↑ SV  
↑ Muscular blood ↑ Shear stress  
↑ NO andVEGF  
Arterioles: ↑ diameter, ↓  
wall thickness, ↑  
volume  
flow  
↑ a-v O2  
extraction  
↑ Flow  
distribution  
CO, cardiac output; HR, heart rate; SV, stroke volume; NO, nitric oxide; VEGF, vascular endothelial  
growth factor; a-v, arterio-venous.  
Physiological and pathological cardiac adaptations  
17  
2.1 Central adaptations  
During physical exercise, the heart provides for the muscle increased supply  
of O2 by increasing the cardiac flow rate, which quickly adapts to demand  
(in about 5–10s). Continuing the exercise, the cardiac output continues to  
increase from about 5L/min at rest to about 15–20L/min at the peak of  
a dynamic effort, also leading to a parallel increase inVO2. Instead, during  
isometric exercise,there is no linearity of increment between cardiac output  
andVO2, with a higher cardiac work at equalVO2.  
Flow rate modification is similar in men and women, even if women  
have a slightly higher flow rate with the sameVO2.This is because they have  
a lower capacity for the transport of O2 due to lower hemoglobin levels.  
However, the maximum cardiac output that can be reached by women,  
trained or not, is lower than that of men, even if at the highest levels the  
differences between gender are attenuated [3].  
At rest, cardiac output has similar values in sedentary subjects and ath-  
letes. However, the latter can reach much higher maximum cardiac output  
values (30–35L/min, exceptionally 40L/min) with a sixfold to sevenfold  
increase. The increase in cardiac output (CO) is achieved through two  
mechanisms: the increase in heart rate (HR) and the increase in stroke  
volume (SV).  
2.1.1 Heart rate  
During dynamic exercises, HR increases linearly with the intensity of the  
effort, both in trained and untrained subjects. However, in emotional peo-  
ple, it is not uncommon to observe an increase in HR and systolic arterial  
pressure immediately before the exercise.This phenomenon is called an an-  
ticipatory response and is mediated by the sympathetic nervous system due  
to the activation of the bulbar centers by the upper cortical centers.Starting  
a submaximal exercise, HR increases very fast, similarly to cardiac output,  
because of a muscle-cardiac reflex [4], which starts from a mechanical or  
chemical peripheral receptor and causes rapid vagal tone abolition [5].The  
progressive increase of adrenergic stimulation on the sinoatrial node and the  
effect of the catecholamines released from the adrenal medulla are respon-  
sible for the further increase of HR. Continuing the exercise with constant  
intensity, HR continues to increase and reaches, within 30–40s, 80%–90%  
of the value of the steady state. If the exercise continues, beyond 5–10min  
is possible a slight further HR increase is accompanied by a parallel grad-  
ual reduction of SV, with unchanged CO.This phenomenon is known as  
“cardiovascular drift” and is related to the increase in body temperature.  
18  
Athlete’s heart  
A prolonged physical effort is responsible for the reduction of circulating  
blood volume especially if the ambient temperature is high, due to the loss  
of water by sweating and the redistribution of blood to the skin to facili-  
tate the loss of heat and to maintain a constant body temperature.This is  
responsible for a decrease in the venous return to the right heart and the SV,  
which is compensated by the increase in HR.That is why in long-lasting  
endurance competitions, the highest HR is registered at the end of the race  
[6]. If the intensity of the effort increases, rather than remaining constant,  
a proportional increase in HR is observed with each increase in load, with  
kinetics similar to that described above except for the time to reach equilib-  
rium that is lengthened as the intensity raises.When the exercise stops, the  
kinetics of HR return to baseline is similar to that of its growth unless the  
exercise has used anaerobic mechanisms. In this case, the recovery is slower.  
Moreover, it would be faster if the effort is stopped abruptly and/or the  
subject recovers in a clinostat position.  
Almost 40years ago a study introduced the concept of “cardiac fatigue,”  
identified as the reduction of heart performance after a long-lasting exercise,  
as marathons and ultramarathons characterized by the appearance, imme-  
diately after the race, of echocardiographic alterations of ventricular func-  
tion, especially diastolic, which disappear in 24–48h [7]. It would be linked  
to ultrastructural and molecular damage of cardiomyocytes, responsible for  
raising blood levels of markers, such asTroponin I andT [8] very similar to  
what occurs in the skeletal muscles where delayed onset muscle soreness  
(DOMS) is characterized by microscopic, transient, and diffuse damage of  
muscle cells as a result of exercises of considerable intensity.  
It has been hypothesized that this mechanism could be the origin of  
a new nosologic entity, called Phidippides cardiomyopathy, in which sus-  
tained cardiac output leads to transitory chamber dilation and induce car-  
diac fibrosis with possibly severe consequences on athlete’s health [9].  
2.1.2 Stroke volume  
The HR increase is the main factor responsible for CO increase during  
exercise.The SV increase has a minor role. Indeed, the biggest variation in  
SV occurs at the beginning of the exercise,during the transition phase from  
rest to moderate work, and at low workloads (up to 50% ofVO2 max).  
The raise of SV is related to the Frank-Starling mechanism, sparked  
by the increase in venous return, with a greater ventricular filling and a  
bigger tele-diastolic volume which follows the myocardial fibers stretch-  
ing and strengthening ventricular contraction.As the intensity of the effort  
Physiological and pathological cardiac adaptations  
19  
increases,the increase in the SV tends to flatten and then reduce,because of  
the shortening of the diastolic phase with lower ventricular filling.  
SV is influenced by the body position. Standing at rest SV is lower  
than in supine position. So, its increase is proportionally greater during  
orthostatic than clinostatic exercise. In addition, SV is strongly influenced  
by afterload.That is why in isometric exercise with generalized peripheral  
vasoconstriction and higher arterial pressure values SV increases less or de-  
creases, with augmented ventricular wall stress [10].  
2.2 Peripheral adaptations  
During physical exercise not only the CO but also the vascular conduc-  
tance,the perfusion capacity of the muscle,and the tissue oxygen extraction  
increase. Different studies reveal an increased oxidative capacity and in-  
creased capillary density in trained muscles [11].The consequent increase  
of the muscular blood flow, which can achieve 25 times the basal value,  
depends mainly on the dilation of the muscular arteries and the massive  
recruitment of new capillary districts.  
It has clearly been shown that shear stress is a central factor in vascular  
adaptations to training.Shear stress,which is the force that the blood applies  
to the endothelial cells as it flows through the blood vessel, is enhanced  
during endurance training when the perfusion of the muscle is severely  
increased. Shear stress is sensed by mechanosensory receptors on the endo-  
thelial cells leading to an acute increase of NO production and therefore in  
vascular conductance but, more importantly, it also influences the expres-  
sion of proteins in the vascular wall, such as the vascular endothelial growth  
factor (VEGF), that has a great role in arteriogenesis and vascular function  
and growth.  
To accommodate the higher muscular perfusion rates in trained subjects,  
arteries undergo structural adaptations leading to an increased diameter and  
reduced wall thickness and the volume of the arteriolar net is increased.  
Endurance training has been observed to increase the maximal vasodilator  
capacity, not only in the dimension but also in the number of arteries and  
arterioles. Moreover, the growth differed depending on fiber type, occur-  
ring in the muscles mainly used during the training:for example,endurance  
training primarily leads to arteriolarization in oxidative and fast oxidative  
glycolytic fibers [12].  
Wall vascular thickness is also affected by training.It is proportionally re-  
duced with endurance training both in the forearm and leg.This means that  
is possible to observe an increased arterial wall thickness in parallel with an  
20  
Athlete’s heart  
increase in arterial diameter.Instead,heavy load resistance training induces a  
large increase in blood pressure and has an impact on the arterial wall thick-  
ness similar to hypertension,increasing wall thickness without an equivalent  
effect on diameter leading to a higher wall thickness to diameter ratio.This  
difference results in different vascular compliance because of changes in the  
wall composition and is responsible for the ability to mantain a high flow  
in the diastolic phase and also a high stroke volume in endurance-trained  
athletes [13].Also for coronary arteries it has been reported a relationship  
between diameter and cardiac dimension in top-level athletes, indicating  
a training-induced enlargement of coronary arteries. Moreover, at a func-  
tional level, coronary diameters increase with adenosine infusion, or dipyr-  
idamole, and this is greater in endurance athletes than in sedentary subjects,  
indicating a greater flow reserve.That is why a period of endurance training  
is useful to increase coronary flow reserve also in patients with coronary  
disease [14].  
Another frequently observed outcome of endurance training that affects  
the magnitude of blood flow to the muscle during submaximal exercise is  
an increased arterio-venous O2 extraction. It is the result of cellular adapta-  
tion to exercise with increased number and size of mitochondria and aug-  
mented aerobic enzyme activity leading to an improved muscle’s metabolic  
capacity in physical activity.  
Finally, a training-induced adaptation that may influence the level of  
blood flow to the active muscle is an improved flow distribution resulting  
from a more optimal vascular architecture or a more precise neural control  
of blood flow, with a consequent smaller portion of the blood being dis-  
tributed to nonactive muscle or internal organs less involved in the exercise.  
While at rest only 15%–20% of the whole total blood mass is directed to  
muscles, during maximal endurance exercise it can reach 80%–85%, thanks  
to an increase in vasoconstrictor tone in most organs, overall splanchnic. In  
this region, vasoconstriction is useful to avoid the possible pressure drop  
caused by massive vasodilatation.  
3 Physiological modifications in different sports  
The phenomenon of cardiovascular adaptation that occurs as a conse-  
quence of physical exercise has its fundamentals in the different hemody-  
namic situations to which the heart is submitted. These are the primary  
and fundamental stimuli for cardiac remodeling that depends also on the  
type of exercise. Indeed, exercise can be separated into two principal forms  
Physiological and pathological cardiac adaptations  
21  
of physical activity: (1) endurance training, characterized by sustained ele-  
vations in cardiac output with reduced peripheral vascular resistance (i.e.,  
long-distance running, cycling, rowing, and swimming), and (2) strength  
training, characterized by short but intense bouts of increased peripheral  
vascular resistance and only slightly elevated cardiac output (i.e., weightlift-  
ing, track-and-field throwing events).  
Since 1975, it has been introduced the notion that these two forms of  
exercise lead to different exercise-induced adaptations in cardiac structure  
[15]. Specifically, athletes exposed to endurance training demonstrated ec-  
centric LV enlargement, due to a volume overload that increased diastolic  
wall stress. The adaptation of the LV to this work is eccentric ventricu-  
lar hypertrophy, characterized by an increase of both ventricular mass and  
ventricular cavity dimension.Athletes exposed to strength training instead,  
demonstrated concentric LV hypertrophy, characterized by normal cavity  
dimensions, but increased wall thickness and mass because of a pressure  
overload and increased systolic wall stress. So, both these models result in  
increased LV mass [16] (Fig. 1).  
Fig. 1 Hypertrophic adaptations of the heart to different types of sports activities.  
22  
Athlete’s heart  
Table 2 Schematic representation of the four different types of sport disciplines, with  
the common hemodynamic changes and cardiac remodeling indicated.  
Strength  
disciplines  
Endurance  
disciplines  
Skill disciplines  
Mixed disciplines  
↑/↑↑ HR  
↑ BP  
↑↑ HR  
↑↑/↑↑↑ HR  
↑↑ BP  
↑↑↑ HR  
↑↑↑ BP  
↑↑ BP  
↑ CO  
↑↑ CO  
↑↑/↑↑↑ CO  
↑↑Volume of  
training  
↑↑↑ CO  
-Volume of  
training  
↑Volume of  
training  
↑↑↑Volume of  
training  
- Cardiac  
↑ Cardiac  
remodeling  
Weightlifting,  
wrestling  
↑↑ Cardiac  
remodeling  
Basketball,  
football,  
↑↑↑ Cardiac  
remodeling  
Cycling, triathlon,  
rowing,  
remodeling  
Archery, curling,  
golf, table tennis  
volleyball,  
gymnastics  
canoeing  
HR, heart rate; BP, blood pressure; CO, cardiac output.  
Adapted from Pelliccia A, Sharma S, Gati S, Bäck M, Börjesson M, Caselli S, et al., ESC Scientific  
Document Group. 2020 ESC guidelines on sports cardiology and exercise in patients with cardiovascu-  
lar disease. Eur Heart J 2021;42(1):17–96.  
This hypothesis, called the “Morganroth Hypothesis” from the name  
of the scientist who developed it, has been questioned in recent literature  
suggesting that the increase in LV mass is proportional to the increase in  
LV volume (balanced remodeling) irrespective of the sports discipline and  
normal LV geometry can be frequently observed also in top-level athletes.  
The Morganroth Hypothesis has also some limitations because many sports,  
such as rowing or cycling, imply both endurance and strength muscle ac-  
tivities, and the hypertrophy results in an intermediate phenotype (mixed)  
(Table 2) [17]. Moreover, also skill sports exist, such as archery, golf, sailing,  
and shooting.  
3.1 Endurance sports  
It is well known for a long time that endurance training leads to adaptations  
in the cardiovascular system.These changes take place both in cardiac mus-  
cle and in arterial structure,resulting in an increased aerobic power through  
greater oxygen extraction, greater perfusion capacity of the muscle, in-  
creased vascular conductance, and increased cardiac output [18,19] (Fig. 2).  
Two types of adaptations occur. Central (cardiac) adaptations and pe-  
ripheral adaptations involving arteries, capillaries, and blood flow.  
First of all, typical of endurance cardiovascular adaptation is bradycar-  
dia at rest and during submaximal effort, compared to the heart rate of  
Physiological and pathological cardiac adaptations  
23  
Fig. 2 Myocardial work of an endurance athlete, showing optimal global work effi-  
ciency (98%).  
nontrained subjects during the same physical work.It seems to be the result  
of a reduction of the sympathetic tone and of the intrinsic heart rate, evi-  
denced by lower levels of circulating catecholamines in endurance athletes.  
Cardiac output is the first parameter that increases, starting a physical ex-  
ercise [20]. In fact, it can increase from ∼5L/min at rest to ∼15L/min in  
young females [21] and ∼20L/min in young males [22] and up to ∼25 to 30  
and ∼35 to 40L/min in elite female and male athletes, respectively, during  
maximal exercise engaging a large muscle mass [23]. The structural and  
functional modification in the heart,leading to such an important improve-  
ment of performance was first described by Henschen more than 100years  
ago, who identified enlargement of the heart, specifically hypertrophy and  
dilatation, due to athletic activity using only a basic physical examination  
with careful percussion [24].  
These findings have been subsequently confirmed by technology: first  
chest radiography and then echocardiography provided the possibility to  
evaluate in detail training-induced morphologic and functional changes in  
the trained heart [25] (Fig. 3). Accordingly, many morphological features,  
such as increased end-diastolic dimensions of the right ventricle and left  
ventricle,LV hypertrophy,increased LV mass,but also modifications of both  
atria are now well-established hallmarks of the cardiomegaly, the second  
component of the so-called athlete’s heart.  
24  
Athlete’s heart  
Fig. 3 HyperDoppler flow analysis in an endurance athlete, showing low energy dissi-  
pation of intracardiac vortexes during the ejection phase.  
As discussed before, cardiac output is sensibly affected by different non-  
genetic characteristics of the athlete, such as age and gender.This happens  
also because body size, which is generally smaller in women, has a large  
influence on heart size and so the stroke volume in women is lower than  
in men [26].That is why the measures have to be always indexed for BSA.  
Larger athletes generally show greater absolute LV cavity and thickness di-  
mension, which normalizes when corrected for BSA.The smallest part of  
heart dimensions and functions may rather depend on genetic factors and  
ethnicity may play an important role [27]. Black athletes show often major  
LV wall thickness with normal LV cavities, demonstrating that race is a pre-  
disposing factor to an increased wall thickness rather than to an increased  
LV cavity [28].  
Even if during exercise most of the cardiac output increase is due to the  
higher heart rate, the maximal heart rate is relatively unaltered with exer-  
cise training, with some evidence indicating that heart rate may be reduced  
during maximal exercise with training [29].Consequently,the large increase  
in cardiac output associated with exercise training is the result of a larger  
Physiological and pathological cardiac adaptations  
25  
stroke volume.Stroke volume rises during exercise as a result of increases in  
LV end-diastolic volume and, to a lesser extent, sympathetically mediated  
reduction in end-systolic volume.LV end-diastolic volume is determined by  
diastolic filling, which is determined by a complex interplay between heart  
rate, intrinsic myocardial relaxation, ventricular compliance, ventricular fill-  
ing pressures, atrial contraction, and pericardial and pulmonary constraints  
[30]. An increase in stroke volume with exercise training could, therefore,  
potentially be a result of changes in one or more of these variables.  
As said above LV is one of the most involved heart chambers during the  
adaptation to endurance exercise. Many cross-sectional studies have high-  
lighted increased LV end-diastolic diameter [31,32], LV wall thickness, and  
LV mass [33] in endurance athletes, overall in elite male athletes with large  
body sizes [34], because of the mechanism described before (Fig. 4).  
The sequence of events with which adaptation occurs has been shown  
in longitudinal training studies that have interestingly reported that in the  
first phase of training at a lower intensity (0–6months) there is only an  
increase in LV mass, which pattern and magnitude depends on the kind of  
sport. Some sports such as swimming, cycling, and rowing determine the  
bigger variation of both LV cavity and thickness, whereas athletes partici-  
pating in ultra-endurance sports (for instance, triathlon) paradoxically show  
more modest alterations in cardiac dimensions [27].In the subsequent phase  
of training and with higher intensity an increase in LV end-diastolic volume  
occurs, with restored mass-to-volume ratio [35,36].  
Fig. 4 Cardiac MRI in top-level endurance athlete, showing mainly significant dilatation  
of both LV and RV chambers and mild trabeculation of LV lateral wall. LV, left ventricle;  
RV, right ventricle.  
26  
Athlete’s heart  
In addition to structural adaptations, also LV function undergoes many  
changes with endurance training, particularly the diastolic function. First  
of all, training leads to enhanced early diastolic LV filling and a more rapid  
filling of the heart during high-intensity exercise [37,38]. It is the result  
of the remodeling of the heart, which markedly increases the transmitral  
intraventricular pressure gradient so that blood is rapidly sucked from the  
left atrium into the LV [39]. Moreover, the large end-diastolic LV volume  
is associated with enhanced chamber compliance resulting in greater use of  
the Frank-Starling mechanism and so in preserved ejection fraction [40].  
Otherwise, LV systolic function does not change with endurance exercise.  
LV ejection fraction is generally normal among athletes, and the rate of  
ventricular emptying during exercise plays only a modest role in the aug-  
mentation of stroke volume, which is primarily affected by the adaptations  
in LV diastolic function [41].  
All these adaptation phenomena of the LV represent the consequence of  
chronic endurance physical exercise. Few and conflicting data are available  
about its adaptation immediately after intense physical exercises. Different  
studies indicate a slight reduction of ejection fraction, wall regional abnor-  
malities, and altered diastolic function in runners after a marathon or a de-  
crease of longitudinal, circumferential, and radial strain and a reduction and  
delay of peak twisting in triathletes after a long exercise.All this often comes  
with an increase of both troponin and brain natriuretic peptide and suggests  
the occurrence of “cardiac fatigue” in these exercise conditions [42,43].  
Moreover, after a period of de-training, the LV adaptation regresses.  
With a “physical de-conditioning” of about 3months, it has been demon-  
strated a reduction of the septal wall thickness, whereas the reduction of  
both septal thickness (of about 15%) and LV cavity dimension (of about  
7%) may be observed after 1–13years of de-training.This demonstrated that  
the LV cavity reduces more slowly and slightly than the LV wall thickness.  
This phenomenon of regression of the athlete’s heart allows a differential  
diagnosis with pathologic hypertrophy (as in dilated cardiomyopathy and  
hypertrophic cardiomyopathy) in which the hypertrophy does not decrease  
after a period of de-training [44].  
At the same time and proportionally to the adaptation of the LV, also  
the other cardiac chambers change in the endurance athlete.While the LV  
adaptation becomes evident only after training lasting several months, the  
right heart undergoes very rapid changes and so the effects of physical ex-  
ercise on the RV are just evident immediately, whereas the LV dimensions  
do not change in the acute phase postexercise [45].  
Physiological and pathological cardiac adaptations  
27  
The right ventricle is the first chamber to show the adaptation of the  
athlete’s heart because of its key role during endurance exercise.This happens  
because endurance exercise is aerobic work that requires greater oxygen sup-  
ply to the muscle tissue, and cardiac output has to increase substantially.This  
determines an augmented venous return to the right chambers and dilatation  
of pulmonary arteries, which progressively enlarge during the physical exer-  
cise more than the LV to adequately collect the venous return [44].  
Several studies have shown that during exercise, pulmonary artery sys-  
tolic pressure increases proportionally with the cardiac output and is associ-  
ated with the enhancement of pulmonary vascular reserve [46]. Its increase  
is greater than the invasively-measured systolic blood pressure increase,  
demonstrating that RV wall stress and work are much higher than the LV  
work during endurance exercise [47,48].  
During intense exercise of short duration,there is an increased RV func-  
tion and volume work overload, but it can recover completely at the end of  
training. Continuous endurance training causes also chronic adaptations on  
RV that undergo eccentric remodeling.The RV-free walls appear thicker in  
endurance athletes (≥5mm) and also all the diameters of the RV are aug-  
mented, demonstrating the whole chamber enlargement [28].This change  
in RV dimensions is strongly related to LV stroke volume and pulmonary  
artery systolic pressure, demonstrating that there is a high interdependence  
of the two ventricles in the athlete’s heart.  
The RV enlargement is responsible for the very frequent presence of a  
tricuspid valve regurgitation, which is often mild and that, within certain  
limits,can be considered a“physiological consequence”of physical exercise.  
At the same time, also inferior vena cava is larger than in sedentary subjects,  
keeping normal collapsibility in inspiration (Fig. 5).As for LV, also for RV  
parameters exists a positive and significant correlation with body surface  
area (BSA). For this reason, it is necessary to index RV parameters for BSA  
in athletes [49].  
About the RV systolic function in endurance athletes, there have been  
contrasting results, but the latest evidence showed that these individuals have  
an RV systolic function slightly reduced at rest compared to nonathletic sub-  
jects.The greater the RV enlargement, the greater the reduction in RV sys-  
tolic function. Moreover, the regional systolic function of the inlet, the basal  
portion, and of the mid free wall of the RV, seem significantly lower than  
the function in the same regions in nonathletes. However, a recent echocar-  
diographic study demonstrated that a mild reduction in RV function can be  
considered a physiologic adaptation explained by the increased end-diastolic  
28  
Athlete’s heart  
Fig. 5 Dilated inferior cava vein in an endurance athlete, with normal inspiratory  
collapse.  
volume with a normal stroke volume that causes a reduced ejection fraction  
[28]. In another study, it has been shown that regional systolic wall anomalies  
at rest normalize themselves at the peak of exercise, not being the result of  
ventricular damage, but a physiological adaptation in response to RV dilata-  
tion and demonstrating a preserved contractile reserve [50].  
There are nonunivocal data in changes of the RV diastolic function in  
endurance athletes. Anyway, it has been demonstrated that only age and  
heart rate, and no other factors, such as the amount of endurance exercise,  
influence the diastolic parameters. So, if an altered diastolic function of RV  
is found in a young athlete, it could indicate underlying heart disease and  
require further investigation [51].  
During physical exercise,the volume overload of the right chambers also  
involves the right atrium.This chamber normally supports the filling of the  
RV not representing just a“passive conduit”to the RV in early diastole and  
completing the RV filling with an active contraction, which contributes to  
30% of RV cardiac output.The right atrium undergoes an acute increase  
in dimension. Such enlargement, in an athlete who performs an endurance  
exercise at a competitive level for a long-term period, persists also at rest.  
Many observational studies demonstrate a prevalence of RA dilatation  
[51,52].They suggest that type of sport and BSA are the main determinants  
of RA dimension,with bigger value in endurance sports and higher BSA vs  
strength sports and lower BSA. Gender also determines a difference in the  
RA area, with higher values in men, even if this difference disappears when  
the values are indexed for BSA. Evidence was instead not found about the  
influence of ethnicity on the RA dimension [53].  
The adaptation of the athlete’s heart also involves the LA,which presents  
a larger dimension in the athletes, because LA pressure and volume increase  
Physiological and pathological cardiac adaptations  
29  
during exercise [54]. In athletes, LA adaptation is not isolated but is always  
associated with LV cavity enlargement. During ventricular diastole, the LV  
pressure is transmitted back to the LA.During diastole, LV filling pressure  
increases, and it is necessary that also LA pressure rises to obtain a complete  
LV filling.This mechanism determines LA enlargement and stretches atrial  
cardiomyocytes. Several echocardiographic studies on competitive athletes  
found an increase in LA size with a strong proportional relationship with  
LV cavity enlargement and with type and duration of training. Because of  
the large percentage of athletes with LA mild dilatation, it is now consid-  
ered a physiologic adaptation to exercise [55,56].  
From a functional point of view, LA enlargement could be interpreted  
as a loss of the fundamental function of this chamber determining the ad-  
equate LV filling and as a risk factor for developing atrial fibrillation. It has  
recently been demonstrated that the atrial function, expressed by LA strain,  
is normal in elite athletes compared with age-matched sedentary healthy  
controls and hypertensive patients.Thus, the atrial enlargement of the ath-  
lete’s heart does not mean loss of atrial function, but, conversely, it indicates  
an increase of functional capacity during exercise [57]. Regarding the pos-  
sible role of endurance exercise in causing the onset of atrial fibrillation,  
several studies have demonstrated that the incidence of this arrhythmia is  
higher in athletes compared to sedentary controls and that the risk of AF  
correlates with hours and intensity of exercise [58,59].This is probably due  
to an increased vagal tone with atrial ectopic beats mixed with a profibrotic  
process, associated with the acute postexercise release of inflammation  
and oxidative factors that favors the excitability of myocardium creating  
the substrate for a re-entry circuit.Typically, this arrhythmia is paroxysmal  
self-limiting AF and occurs during the night or after meals, demonstrating  
that the increased vagal tone is an important trigger [60,61].  
A daily,constant,and less intense exercise,such as walking,is rather asso-  
ciated with significantly lowerAF incidence in older adults.An exercise risk  
threshold for developingAF has been identified,corresponding to a lifetime  
exercise practice of more than 5000h and a weekly time of more than 5h  
at the age of 30years or over [62,63].  
3.2 Strength sports  
Strength sports are disciplines in which the heart performs a so-called“pres-  
sure”work,differently from the“volume”work typical of endurance sports.  
By practicing these disciplines,the athlete can achieve the goal of improving  
strength rather than endurance. In this type of activity, it has been verified  
that even if for very short times,the blood pressure can reach values of even  
30  
Athlete’s heart  
350mmHg of systolic and 200mmHg of diastolic blood pressure during the  
phase of maximal muscular concentric contraction against resistance [64].  
This kind of effort is followed by the establishment of an adaptive frame-  
work for the cardiovascular system.This is identifiable with the appearance  
of moderate concentric hypertrophy of the left ventricle, with a homo-  
geneous, or slightly more represented at the level of the interventricular  
septum, increase in the thickness of the walls [65] (Fig. 6).  
Hypertrophy, which is the increase in myocardial mass due to parallel  
replication of sarcomeres, is the consequence of repeated increases in the  
left ventricular afterload, of the resulting wall stress that this overload deter-  
mines during each repetition in isometric exercise and of the compensa-  
tory hyperdynamic state,characterized by increased heart rate,which occurs  
during the effort and in the subsequent recovery phase [66].  
Initially,this adaptation has been little accepted due to the absence of the  
main characteristics of the “athlete’s heart” recognized in the past decades,  
such as bradycardia and the increase of the cardiac shadow at the chest  
X-ray.Subsequently,several studies have shown the constant presence of this  
type of adaptation in athletes engaged in power sports, despite the difficul-  
ties resulting from training programs not always extremely categorical and  
composed of purely static exercises [67].  
The impact of strength training on the RV remains uncertain due to in-  
consistent and limited data.If compared with the greatest cardiac remodeling  
Fig. 6 Cardiac MRI in top-level power athlete, showing a mainly significant increase in  
LV wall thickness, with a concentric model of LV hypertrophy. RV, right ventricle; LV, left  
ventricle.  
Physiological and pathological cardiac adaptations  
31  
associated with endurance exercise, strength training seems to impact min-  
imally on the right ventricle (RV). Even after long-term strength training,  
RV dimensions appear greater in endurance athletes of high categories.Also,  
the right atrium is subjected to only transient pressure overload that nor-  
malizes at rest. Differently, during endurance exercise, the volume overload  
causes an acute increase of RA dimension that persists also at rest. This  
different mechanism explains the difference in the dimensions of RA in  
endurance athletes, often higher than in strength athletes.  
4 Special environment  
Sport activities in different kinds of environmental conditions could influ-  
ence cardiac adaptations (Table 3).  
Table 3 Special environments cardiac adaptations.  
Hyperbarism  
↓ BP  
↓ CO  
Peripheral vasoconstriction  
Lactate accumulation  
Blood shift: right chamber dilatation, Bainbridge reflex,  
BNP release  
Arterial hypoxia  
Hyperventilation  
↑ HR  
Hypobarism  
↑ SBP  
Heat environment ↓ Plasma volume  
↑ Cardiac chamber volume and diameter  
↑ SV  
= CO  
Cold environment ↑ SV  
↑ SBP  
↓ HR  
Arrhythmias  
Cold shock: inspiratory gasp, hyperventilation, hypocapnia,  
↑ HR, ↑ CO, peripheral vasoconstriction, ↑ SBP  
Diving response: ↓ HR, apnea, vasoconstriction in trunk  
and limbs  
Air pollution  
Pulmonary congestion  
Distress of alveolar-capillary membrane  
↑ SBP  
CO, cardiac output; HR, heart rate; SV, stroke volume; SBP, systolic blood pressure; BNP, brain natri-  
uretic peptide.  
32  
Athlete’s heart  
4.1 Hyperbarism  
If the external pressure on the human body is augmented (hyperbarism),  
the cardiovascular system undergoes particular modifications.In underwater  
activities, these changes depend on the depth reached and on the duration  
of the dive which affect the O2 availability and the total lung capacity.  
At rest, rather than of minimum muscle work, cardiovascular response to  
immersion in apnea is characterized mainly by bradycardia, CO reduc-  
tion, peripheral vasoconstriction with systemic arterial pressure increase,  
and lactate accumulation in under-perfused muscles recurring to anaerobic  
metabolism. Of course, adaptation changes if, during the dive, the subject  
performs a physical exercise and it is also influenced by other external fac-  
tors, including water temperature [68].  
Bradycardia is certainly the most studied phenomenon because it is eas-  
ily monitored. During apnea diving, there is a progressive HR reduction,  
which occurs mostly in the first 20–30m and lasts for the whole dive.The  
initial bradycardia is linked in part to the “diving reflex,” present in many  
animals, including fishing birds.The reflex, evoked by the simple face im-  
mersion in water, is responsible for a complex cardiorespiratory response,  
characterized by bradycardia, apnea, and peripheral vasoconstriction, which  
are all mechanisms for the conservation of oxygen.The afferent branch of  
the reflex is mainly localized in the trigeminal nerve, while the efferent  
branch consists of both a vagal component, responsible for bradycardia and  
an adrenergic component responsible for vasoconstriction. A further HR  
reduction, up to minimum values of 20–25bpm, can be observed at large  
depths, along with the possible occurrence of various forms of arrhythmia,  
such as sinus arrest, nodal or ventricular escapement rhythms, and prema-  
ture beats. HR modifications when diving with self-contained underwater  
air-breathing apparatus are quite different:after moderate initial bradycardia,  
probably linked to the diving reflex, the HR trend depends on the effort  
made and seems to be slightly greater than on the earth [69].  
Other typical cardiovascular changes, present in apnea and also diving  
with self-contained underwater air breathing apparatus, are due to the pe-  
culiar blood redistribution in the various districts of the body, called“blood  
shift".This phenomenon is characterized by a conspicuous return of blood  
from the periphery, meaning from lower limbs and abdominal organs, in-  
side the thoracic cage and aims to avoid thorax implosion and lung collapse  
being fluids incompressible. Second, it provides an increased venous return  
to the heart and the maintenance of an adequate CO.This is then respon-  
sible for the right chambers dilatation and pulmonary hypertension that is  
Physiological and pathological cardiac adaptations  
33  
proportional to the depth reached. Right chamber dilatation causes two  
main consequences. The first, called the Bainbridge reflex, is due to the  
stimulation of atrial volume receptors and determines tachycardia.This is  
contrasted and overcome by the cardioinhibitory response evoked by aortic  
baroceptors stimulated by the distention of aortic walls.The second conse-  
quence is the release of atrial natriuretic peptide, which is responsible for  
the increase in diuresis commonly observed after immersion.  
On the contrary, after the ascent and the first breath is possible to ob-  
serve a characteristic tachycardia, maintained for a few minutes [70].  
4.2 Hypobarism  
Altitude’s physiologic challenge comes directly from decreased ambient  
PO2, not from reduced total barometric pressure or any change in the rela-  
tive concentrations of gases in inspired air.  
Air density decreases progressively with ascent above sea level and, with  
the fall in barometric pressure upon ascending to higher elevations, also the  
PO2 of air decreases.The arterial hypoxia that accompanies the reduction in  
PO2 precipitates both the immediate physiologic adjustments to the altitude  
and the longer-term process of acclimatization.The term altitude acclimatiza-  
tion broadly describes adaptive responses in physiology and metabolism that  
improve tolerance to altitude hypoxia. Each adjustment to a higher elevation  
proceeds progressively and full acclimatization requires an appropriate time.  
This phenomenon starts at a moderate altitude of about 2000m and is com-  
posed of immediate responses to altitude exposure and long-term adjustments.  
Immediate response is characterized mainly by an increase in the re-  
spiratory drive to produce hyperventilation that can remain elevated also  
for years during prolonged altitude residence. This causes an elevation in  
alveolar PO2 responsible for easier oxygen loading in the lungs. Also, the  
cardiovascular system has increased response in this situation. An increase  
in HR is one of the earliest responses to high altitude.The mechanism be-  
hind this increase, particularly during exercise, is only partially understood.  
Undoubtedly,increased sympathetic activity and circulating catecholamines  
play an important role in increasing HR at rest but both vagal withdrawal  
and an increase in sympathetic activity are probably responsible for the rise  
in resting HR with altitude.With chronic altitude exposure, at rest, data are  
conflicting on whether HR is normalized or maintains slightly elevated  
with acclimatization [71].However,in this situation,there is enhanced para-  
sympathetic activity responsible for a decrease in maximum HR and for  
the change in HR during exercise when compared to sea-level values [72].  
34  
Athlete’s heart  
Another parameter that seems to affect the response to altitude is age.  
Indeed, older subjects showed less adaptation and a reduced cardiovascu-  
lar response to altitude, while sex does not affect it [73].The BP changes  
during both acute and chronic altitude exposure are well established: first,  
there is a decrease in systolic BP due to hypoxic vasodilation, which is  
quickly (within a few hours) counteracted by an increase in sympathetic  
vasoconstriction, which raises systolic blood pressure (SBP) above sea-level  
values.  
With chronic altitude exposure, systemic hypertension is well docu-  
mented.The rise in SBP is evident even after only moderate altitude ex-  
posure.This level of altitude is easily reachable by those with cardiovascular  
diseases and so may have important clinical applications.This systemic va-  
soconstriction is linear with plasma noradrenaline concentration but also  
other mechanisms must be at least partially responsible [74], such as com-  
pensatory polycythemia, which increases blood volume, and the role of  
the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). Different studies have  
shown an acute decrease in plasma levels of renin, aldosterone, and angio-  
tensin II at an altitude that rise to normal levels with acclimatization, and  
RAAS inhibition is a practical way to control the rise in BP at altitude,  
although it may not be as effective as it is at sea level [75].  
Cardiac output (CO) is known to increase with acute exposure to alti-  
tude to preserve O2 delivery to tissues.Tachycardia is the key reason for this  
increase in CO, but the role of stroke volume (SV) remains controversial.  
The part played by SV in CO increase with altitude is debatable. However,  
nowadays the most reliable evidence showed a significant increase in SV  
with acute exposure to genuine altitude [76]. Following this acute increase  
in SV, there is a good evidence base for a chronic reduction in SV follow-  
ing acclimatization, returning CO to normal physiological levels or lower.  
It has been shown that altered filling of the ventricles may be responsible.  
The reason for this is most likely due to reduced preload, which is due to  
pulmonary vasoconstriction.This is a significant consequence of hypoxia at  
high altitudes and,typically,it causes a redistribution of blood to areas of the  
lung that are better ventilated, improving oxygen saturation.Although this  
is a useful compensatory mechanism when only a small region of the lung  
is affected, when there is widespread hypoxia throughout the lung, as with  
altitude, vasoconstriction causes pulmonary hypertension [77].  
Maximum achievable CO with chronic altitude exposure seems to de-  
crease.The main theory for this is that muscle function is decreased at al-  
titude, limiting its need for increased blood flow while even if it has been  
Physiological and pathological cardiac adaptations  
35  
initially considered, the myocardial function is maintained up to 5000m,  
despite hypoxemia [77]. In hypobaric conditions and other situations of  
extreme exercise or normal exercise under extreme environmental con-  
ditions, a key role is played by the alveolar-capillary barrier that becomes  
disrupted with the appearance of pulmonary congestion and B-lines at lung  
ultrasound.The acute appearance of B-lines is a harbinger of high-altitude  
mountain sickness in high-altitude trekkers and can appear also after apnea  
diving or marathon runners.The presence of pulmonary congestion limits  
the efficiency of gas exchange and is likely to be a contributing limiting  
factor of performance in athletes [78–80].  
4.3 Heat adaptation  
Many studies have shown that humans have a remarkable ability to adapt  
to heat stress and, given adequate water and protection from the sun, a  
healthy heat-acclimated individual can tolerate extended exposure to vir-  
tually any natural weather-related heat stress. Heat acclimatization induces  
physiological adaptations that improve thermoregulation, reduce the risk of  
serious heat illness, and improve aerobic performance in general but overall  
in hot environments. Indeed, since 1768, when James Lind published the  
first report on the ability of humans to adapt to environmental heat, it is  
known that environmental heat stress (given from the interaction of envi-  
ronmental conditions such as temperature, humidity, and solar radiation)  
and exercise interact to increase physiological strain, which is manifested  
by high core, skin and brain temperatures, increased cardiovascular strain, a  
greater reliance on carbohydrate metabolism, and results in reduced aero-  
bic performance [81]. In these conditions, the work of the heart increases  
considerably, depending on the internal temperature reached and the state  
of hydration.  
Metabolic processes greatly accelerate, with a faster consumption of  
muscle glycogen stocks and a greater increase in oxygen consumption. At  
the same time, the reduction of the plasma volume occurs due to the loss  
of fluids not replenished due to sweating. All this determines precisely a  
greater cardiovascular effort whose first sign is the increase in HR com-  
pared to what happens in a temperate environment at an equal intensity  
of work.This HR increase has been quantified in about 25bpm per each  
°C of increase in rectal temperature or for each 5% of weight lost by the  
subject by dehydration. Such modifications lead to the reduction of athletic  
performance and, potentially, to cardiovascular complications such as acute  
hypotension or heat stroke.  
36  
Athlete’s heart  
Heat acclimatization results in adaptations that reduce the deleterious  
effects of heat stress, enabling the cardiovascular system to provide suffi-  
cient cardiac output to adequately perfuse both skeletal muscle and skin,  
necessary to support heat loss. Heat acclimatization can be founded on  
short-term protocols, till 7days, that offer a physiological and performance  
benefit, or on longer regimens of 8–14days, which is suggested to be more  
effective even if the 75%–80% of the acclimation process occurs in the first  
4–7days [82,83].  
Heat adaption (HA) through acclimatization is attributed to falls in the  
core and skin temperature and a reduction in sympathetic stimulation. It  
seems to be responsible for plasma volume expansion and so of a maintained  
cardiac output, despite lowered heart rate due to compensatory increases in  
stroke volume [84]. Fundamental changes in the cardiac morphology have  
also been identified, following HA, with increased ventricular compliance,  
allowing the ventricle to accept an increased preload, evidenced by an in-  
crease in LA volume and IVC diameter,and then to deliver an increased SV  
without an increase in end-diastolic pressure.This increase in compliance  
improves cardiac efficiency and pressure generation so advantageously to  
increase cardiac output without a significant increase in HR [85].  
4.4 Cold adaptations  
Also, human adaptation to cold may occur through acclimatization and  
includes different responses. Although divergent results exist between the  
studies, the main cold adaptation responses are either insulative (circulatory  
adjustments, increase of fat layer) or metabolic (shivering or nonshivering  
thermogenesis) and may be positive or negative. The pattern of cold ad-  
aptation is dependent on the type (air, water) and intensity (continuous,  
intermittent) of the cold exposure.  
Cold has a profound effect on cardiovascular function during exercise,  
some of which may impact performance.Significant changes occur in heart  
rate, stroke volume, sympathetic nervous activity, total peripheral resistance,  
mean arterial pressure, cardiac work, and myocardial oxygen requirements.  
Maximal heart rate is lower by 10 to 30bpm when the deep body tempera-  
ture is lowered by 0.5°C to 2.0°C.This reduction in maximal heart rate is  
primarily responsible for the reducedVO2 max with body cooling. In con-  
trast to HR, stroke volume increases during cold exposure as a result of the  
translocation of blood from the peripheral/limb circulation to the central  
circulation, increasing central venous pressure and, at the same time, also  
mean arterial blood pressure rises, secondary to an increase in peripheral  
Physiological and pathological cardiac adaptations  
37  
vasoconstriction and systemic vascular resistance. This is the fundamental  
of another cardiovascular change resulting from cold likely that causes a  
decrease in exercise performance, which is a reduction in muscle blood  
flow. Indeed, both aerobic and strength/power performances are decreased  
during cold exposure, with the magnitude of decline related to the fall in  
muscle temperature.  
Humans exhibit peripheral vasoconstriction upon exposure to cold.The  
resulting decrease in peripheral blood flow reduces convective heat transfer  
between the deep body and superficial tissues (skin, subcutaneous fat, and  
skeletal muscle),effectively increasing the insulation of the body.Since heat is  
lost from the exposed body surface faster than it is replaced,skin temperature  
declines. During whole-body exposure to cold, the vasoconstrictor response  
extends beyond the fingers and spreads throughout the entire body’s periph-  
eral circulation. During whole-body cooling, vasoconstriction begins when  
skin temperature falls below about 35°C and becomes maximal when skin  
temperature is about 31°C or less [86].Thus, the vasoconstrictor response to  
cold exposure helps to slow the heat loss and defend deep body temperature,  
but at the expense of a decline in the temperature of peripheral tissue.  
Cold exposure also elicits increased metabolic heat production in hu-  
mans, which can help offset heat loss. In humans, most cold-induced ther-  
mogenesis is attributable to skeletal muscle contractile activity. Humans  
initiate this thermogenesis by voluntarily modifying behavior, that is, in-  
creasing physical activity (e.g., exercise and increased fidgeting), or involun-  
tarily via shivering that consists of repeated rhythmic muscle contractions  
during which most of the metabolic energy expended is liberated as heat  
and little external work is performed.  
Depending on the type of exposure, the impact of cold environments  
on individuals tends to be quite different. Sudden immersion in cold water  
evokes a group of cardiorespiratory responses, initiated by a rapid fall in  
skin temperature, which is collectively known as the “cold shock” response  
and is characterized by an inspiratory gasp, hyperventilation, hypocapnia,  
increased heart rate with increase in cardiac output, peripheral vasocon-  
striction, and hypertension [87].These early cardiovascular responses to im-  
mersion in cold water place a significant and sudden strain on the system  
and are a particular threat to people with coronary heart disease, in whom  
myocardial ischemia is more likely to develop with sudden increases in  
cardiac workload.  
Sudden cold-water immersion of the face during submersion is also  
associated with the diving response. This is characterized by bradycardia,  
38  
Athlete’s heart  
apnea, and vasoconstriction in the trunk and limbs and is evoked by stimu-  
lation of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve [88].Thus, during  
whole-body submersion in cold water, both the cold shock and diving  
response are elicited with concurrent stimulation of, respectively, the sym-  
pathetic and parasympathetic branches of the autonomic nervous system.  
It has been suggested that simultaneous activation of both branches can  
very frequently lead to arrhythmias,overall supra-ventricular and junctional,  
which,in the presence of predisposing factors result in sudden cardiac death  
during immersion. This coactivation of sympathetic and parasympathetic  
activity has been called “autonomic conflict.”  
Prolonged immersion in water at temperatures below thermo-neutrality  
will instead inevitably result in hypothermia, that is a deep body tempera-  
ture below 35°C. If this condition is prolonged with the achievement of  
cardiac temperatures below 28°C, the conduction velocity of the Purkinje  
tissue is slowed to approximate that of myocardial fibers.This predisposes  
the heart to ventricular fibrillation. About the physiological responses to  
cold air exposure, they are the same as cold water immersion (increased  
vasoconstriction, metabolic heat production, and increased sympathetic ac-  
tivity). However, because heat transfer is much less in air versus water, cold  
tolerance is much greater compared to immersion [89].  
4.5 Adaptation to air pollution  
Air quality is an important determinant of performance in athletes, and the  
increase in air pollutants such as fine particulate matter, nitrogen dioxide,  
and ozone has a measurable detrimental effect on the well-being and sport-  
ing performance of competitive athletes.These air pollutants have a detri-  
mental effect of enhancing B-lines as a marker of pulmonary congestion  
and distress of the alveolar-capillary membrane during exercise as docu-  
mented during comprehensive stress echo. B-lines are especially sensitive to  
the air pollutants concentration and the alteration of alveolar-capillary gas  
exchange can probably impact the quality of the performance.Air pollution  
also affects autonomic balance with the increase in sympathetic tone and  
detrimental increase in systolic and diastolic blood pressure during moder-  
ate or strenuous exercise [90–93].  
5 Doping and cardiovascular effects  
Doping in sports is a well-known phenomenon because of its widespread  
use in the past decades,both in elite and in recreational athletes.Its diffusion  
Physiological and pathological cardiac adaptations  
39  
does not seem to be diminished despite great antidoping progress, espe-  
cially because in recreational athletes it is used not only as performance-  
enhancing but also, and maybe especially, as a body-image-enhancing  
method, through the possibility to increase in muscle or decrease in fat  
mass. Indeed, recreational athletes are the group with the highest rates of  
drugs abuse,also nonsport-related [94].For professional athletes,success and  
prestigious results in competitions mean huge profits thanks to sponsors  
and media.While attaining accurate data on the prevalence of their use has  
limitations, studies suggest the illicit use of doping agents by athletes and  
nonathletes may be 1%–5% in the population and greater in some groups;  
with the prevalence being higher in males [95]. In the most common sense  
of the word, doping is the intentional use by the athlete of drugs or meth-  
ods aimed at achieving an improvement in sports performance artificially,  
beyond the limits allowed by training alone.  
The use of doping has its pathophysiological basis in the short-term  
acute responses and in the longer-term adaptations to exercise aformen-  
tioned.The short-term acute responses include elevations in heart rate and  
cardiac output, redistribution of blood flow, increased pulmonary ventila-  
tion, and endocrinological responses.These responses enhance the body’s  
ability to cope with the immediate demands of the current exercise bout,  
for example, through the facilitation of oxygen delivery and its utilization  
by the muscles. Also the longer-term adaptations, such as structural and  
physiological changes of the cardiovascular system,skeletal musculature,and  
hematology, enhance the body’s ability to cope with the demands of sub-  
sequent exercise, increasing the capacity to deliver and utilize oxygen or  
increasing the amount of contractile proteins of the muscle that thereby  
improve the amount of force that they can exert. Such adaptations would  
be seen as improvements in “fitness” and enable the person to potentially  
achieve a higher level of performance in subsequent exercise bouts or  
events. Doping is used to augment these responses and adaptations, thereby  
elevating what the person can achieve to a level above that attainable by  
training alone.  
From an ethical point of view, it is clear that the athlete who uses dop-  
ing breaks the rules of loyalty that characterize the sport.While, therefore,  
substantial research effort has been devoted to the development of reliable  
doping detection assays [96], what is rarely discussed is the adverse effects  
and long-term health consequences of performance-enhancing drugs.This  
lack of emphasis on the health risks of doping agents in the scientific litera-  
ture has resulted in the prevalent belief among athletes that the only adverse  
40  
Athlete’s heart  
Table 4 Cardiovascular consequences of doping substances.  
AAS  
Disfunction of cardiac autonomic regulation  
Atherogenic arrangement: ↑ LDL and hyper-homocysteinemia,  
↓ HDL  
LV hypertrophy (concentric geometry)  
↑ SBP  
Diastolic dysfunction  
Arrhythmias  
GH  
↑ LV mass, PWT, LV diastolic diameters and volumes  
Acromegalic cardiomyopathy: hyperkinetic syndrome, ↑ HR and  
CO, concentric biventricular hypertrophy, DCM with HF  
Salbutamol  
EPO  
Cardiac hypertrophy  
Arrhythmias  
Cocaine  
Vasoconstriction  
Arrhythmias  
DCM with HF  
CO,cardiac output;HR,heart rate;SBP,systolic blood pressure;DCM,dilated cardiomyopathy;HF,heart  
failure; LDL, low-density lipoprotein; HDL, high-density lipoprotein; LV, left ventricle; PWT, poste-  
rior wall thickness; AAS, anabolic androgenic steroids; GH, growth hormone; EPO, erythropoietin.  
consequence of doping is the risk of being caught. In a survey where ath-  
letes were asked if they are willing to misuse performance-enhancing drugs  
that would guarantee an Olympic medal if they could not be caught, 98%  
of athletes said yes [97,98].  
The breakthrough in the protection of the regularity of sports  
events and above all the health of athletes was in 1999 when the WADA  
(World Antidoping Agency) was founded. This super-partes Agency pro-  
vides an annual list of prohibited substances or methods [99] divided  
into three categories: “Substances and Methods Prohibited at All Times  
(in- and out-of-competition)”; “Substances and Methods Prohibited In-  
Competition”; and “Substances Prohibited in Particular Sports.”  
The consequences of the use of these substances on the cardiovascular  
system are very different.Anabolic agents, hormones like growth hormone,  
erythropoietin, beta-2 agonists, and stimulants like cocaine seem to be in-  
volved in modifications in the heart structure that could be responsible for  
health problems (Table 4).  
5.1 Anabolic androgenic steroids  
Anabolic-androgenic steroids (AASs),commonly known as anabolic steroids,  
are a large group of molecules including endogenously produced andro-  
gens, such as testosterone, as well as synthetically manufactured derivatives.  
Physiological and pathological cardiac adaptations  
41  
Testosterone, Nandrolone Decanoate (ND), and methandienone are the  
most commonly abused androgens.AASs use is widespread due to its ability  
to improve muscle growth for esthetic purposes and athletes’ performance,  
minimizing androgenic effects [100]. Indeed, androgens can increase the  
size of muscle fibers as well as muscle strength, and while their use was ini-  
tially restricted to professional bodybuilders, nowadays it has become more  
popular among recreational athletes [101].They are so much used that they  
are the most abused substance among athletes. However, AASs have side  
effects involving all organs,tissues,and body functions,especially long-term  
toxicity involving the cardiovascular system and the reproductive system;  
therefore, their abuse is considered a public health issue.  
The most frequent consequence of exogenous steroid administration is  
cardiac damage.Different mechanisms are involved in this process.Chronic  
assumption of high doses of AASs is primarily responsible for the dysfunc-  
tion in cardiac autonomic regulation, probably due to an uncontrolled  
inflammatory process, with increased sympathetic activity [102] and loss  
of the antioxidant activity exercise-induced [103]. Moreover, it has been  
demonstrated that AASs use is associated with abnormal levels of plasma  
lipoproteins with decreased plasma levels of high-density lipoprotein  
(HDL) cholesterol, the parallel increase of low-density lipoprotein (LDL)  
cholesterol, and hyper-homocysteinemia observed within a few days af-  
ter initiation of steroid use and no effects on triglycerides [104,105].This  
atherogenic arrangement necessarily leads to an increased atherosclerotic  
burden, so 3% of AASs users had myocardial infarction as a consequence  
of atherosclerotic disease [106].The most evident cardiovascular effect of  
AASs assumption with supraphysiological doses of these circulating hor-  
mones is the increased synthesis of the heart muscle with left ventricular  
hypertrophy and hypertension. Indeed, AASs users show higher left ven-  
tricular mass index, thicker left ventricular walls (above all interventricular  
septum), more concentric left geometry, and myocardial mechanical dys-  
function compared to nonusers [107] leading also to reduced left ventri-  
cle relaxation properties [108] (Fig. 7). So, the use of anabolic steroids is  
associated with the loss of the beneficial effects on left ventricle function  
induced by exercise.  
Myocardial ischemia, structural changes, and repolarization impairment  
are hypothesized mechanisms of pro-arrhythmic effects of AASs. Several  
studies reported arrhythmic events in AASs users, mostly all atrial fibrilla-  
tion but also ventricular life-threatening arrhythmias and sudden cardiac  
death [109].  
42  
Athlete’s heart  
Fig. 7 LV pathologic hypertrophy in a power athlete abusing anabolic steroids. Note  
the severe increase in LV wall thickness (A), the impairment of diastolic function both at  
global (B) and regional (C) level, and the diffused reduction of myocardial strain in the  
bull’s eye representation (D). RV, right ventricle; LV, left ventricle.  
Echocardiographic imaging is a useful tool to detect subclinical left ven-  
tricular dysfunction in AASs athlete abusers. New imaging tools, such as  
magnetic resonance, may give fundamental information regarding myocar-  
dial tissue in these cases, being able to highlight myocardial dysfunction,  
myocardial fibrosis, and increased coronary artery calcification.  
5.2 Growth hormone  
The human growth hormone (hGH) is a peptide hormone secreted by  
the pituitary gland. It has been used as a drug in medical treatment in both  
children and adults with hGH deficiency and also for children withTurner  
syndrome. Previously, the only source of hGH was human cadavers, but the  
contamination that led to Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease made this form of treat-  
ment obsolete.In the late 1980s,recombinant hGH (r-hGH) was developed  
through genetic engineering and has been used with good results in the  
treatment of patients with hGH deficiency, allowing bone growth and im-  
pacting on the patient’s final stature, and in other illnesses or injuries such  
as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and after surgery or injury burns.  
Physiological and pathological cardiac adaptations  
43  
Human GH has been also recognized as a potent anabolic agent and  
regulator of body composition in adults [110]. Since the discovery of its  
utility in enhancing sports performance, it has been considered as an ergo-  
genic drug, with effects related to dose and duration of treatment. Its se-  
cretion increases lipolysis and the elimination of lipids with a simultaneous  
increase of lean body mass because it stimulates significantly basal meta-  
bolic rate with preferential use of lipid rather than carbohydrate catabolism.  
Moreover, it affects bone and soft tissue turnover and promotes protein  
synthesis, but most importantly, it works on muscle and muscle-specific  
growth factors.Its use has become widespread among athletes,and not only  
in bodybuilders but also in swimmers and in players taking part in major  
sports events, even thanks to the difficulties in detecting exogenous hGH  
intake in doping controls [111].  
Nevertheless, despite all the observed improvements, it is proven that  
some severe adverse events may occur in hGH-treated individuals: soft-  
tissue edema, fatigue, arthralgias, and carpal tunnel syndrome have been  
experienced significantly more often in treated than in nontreated individ-  
uals [112]. Also, it has been shown that myocardial hypertrophy caused by  
massive abuse of anabolic androgenic steroids by power athletes is further  
worsened by concomitant use of hGH [113]. It is believed that many ath-  
letes may use doses up to 10 times higher than the therapeutic range and are  
at a higher risk of developing diabetes.  
Indeed,although studies in humans on exogenous GH and its effects on  
cardiac structure and function are quite limited, in vivo studies on healthy  
rodents demonstrated that excess GH induces a cardiac hypertrophic re-  
sponse [114]. So, similarly to patients with GH over secretion, athletes who  
use GH as doping can undergo acromegalic cardiomyopathy,which involves  
an early-phase hyperkinetic syndrome with increased heart rate and cardiac  
output,subsequent concentric biventricular hypertrophy,and eventually di-  
lated cardiomyopathy with heart failure. Echocardiography examination in  
rats treated with GH showed significant increases in LV mass, anterior and  
posterior wall thicknesses, LV diastolic diameters and volumes, and cardiac  
output with also increased myocardial contractility [115].  
5.3 Other drugs  
With respect to the possible cardiac hypertrophy induced by many drugs  
that can be used by athletes because of their effect on performance, a men-  
tion is necessary for salbutamol and erythropoietin.  
Salbutamol is the most commonly prescribed medication for broncho-  
spasm and exercise-induced asthma. It is a beta-2 adrenergic agonist that,  
44  
Athlete’s heart  
in some studies, has been identified to have an effect in increasing volun-  
tary muscle strength in men when chronically assumed, while there is no  
published information on its effect on endurance performance [116,117].  
As well as skeletal muscle, also heart has been considered as a possible  
target of the chronic administration of salbutamol, with possible hyper-  
trophic effect. Nevertheless, even if it remains on the list of prohibited  
drugs, the relationship between cardiac hypertrophy and cardiovascular  
beneficial effects has never been demonstrated [118].  
Similarly, erythropoietin, used mainly by endurance athletes because,  
leading to an increase in the erythrocyte mass, is considered to be able to  
allow a greater tolerance to the effort, appears to be responsible for several  
adverse effects. As well as the increase in blood viscosity and all its conse-  
quences, it has been suggested that it would affect the amount and mor-  
phology of the cardiac mitochondria to exploit the increase in hemoglobin  
mass. This would seem to provoke the genesis of mitochondrial cardio-  
myopathy responsible for possible adverse events especially of arrhythmic  
nature [119].  
Finally, cocaine has important cardiovascular effects, and it is largely  
diffused among young people and also in athletes. In addition to a direct  
pro-arrhythmic effect and to a vasoconstrictor action exposing the subject  
to arrhythmic and ischemic events, cocaine use is associated with infiltrates  
of lymphocytes, macrophages, and occasionally eosinophils similar to those  
observed in the case of myocarditis, with focal degeneration and necrosis  
for an increased myocardial concentration of catecholamines or prolonged  
recurrent ischemic episodes. These phenomena could be involved in the  
genesis of dilated cardiomyopathy and congestive heart failure reported in  
these people [120].  
6 Conclusions  
Physical exercise,when carried out regularly and for long periods,can result  
in substantial adaptations of the cardiovascular system that can significantly  
improve athletic performance and can also influence health in sedentary  
individuals.The athlete’s heart is the result of these adaptation mechanisms  
and has different characteristics depending on many nonmodifiable prop-  
erties of the athlete and on the type of exercise. In general, adult male ath-  
letes, those of black ethnicity, and those performing dynamic exercise tend  
to exhibit the largest cardiac dimensions and the most profound electrical  
alterations.Moreover,environmental conditions and drugs can greatly affect  
Physiological and pathological cardiac adaptations  
45  
cardiovascular responses: clinicians must be aware of the pathological and  
clinical consequences, as well as the diagnostic tools, to highlight cardiac  
damages, to consider it in differential diagnosis and undertake primary and  
secondary prevention in their patients.
