This page intentionally left blank  
CHAPTER 5  
Multimodality imaging in  
athlete’s heart  
Antonello D’Andreaa,b, Simona Sperlonganob, and Flavio D’Ascenzic  
aUnit of Cardiology and Intensive Coronary Care,“Umberto I” Hospital, Nocera Inferiore, Italy  
bDivision of Cardiology, Department ofTranslational Medical Sciences, University of Campania “Luigi  
Vanvitelli”, Monaldi Hospital, Naples, Italy  
cDepartment of Medical Biotechnologies, Division of Cardiology, University of Siena, Siena, Italy  
1 Introduction  
The athlete’s heart may overlap with mild phenotypes of cardiac diseases when  
occurring in its most marked expression. The clinician needs to differenti-  
ate this extreme form of physiological adaptation from pathology to prevent  
cardiovascular consequences, including sudden cardiac death (SCD). For this  
purpose, during the cardiovascular evaluation of athletes, the physician should  
follow a practical,diagnostic step-by-step approach,starting from personal and  
family history, physical examination, and standard 12-lead electrocardiogram  
(ECG) and proceeding in selected cases with exercise testing,cardiopulmonary  
exercise testing,echocardiography,cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR),cardiac  
computed tomography (CT), and nuclear imaging [1] (Fig. 1).  
Table 1 summarizes the athletes’ clinical and electrocardiographic fea-  
tures, which are not considered training-related or physiologic adaptations  
to exercise, requiring further investigation.  
2 Exercise stress testing  
Exercise testing is the most widely available functional test. It provides in-  
formation on exercise capacity, heart rate and blood pressure (BP) response  
to exercise, and exercise-induced ECG changes, including arrhythmias.  
Moreover,exercise ECG testing or cardiopulmonary exercise testing (CPET)  
can be useful to evaluate overall cardiovascular health and physical perfor-  
mance of athletes,especially those who are older and engage for the first time  
in moderate to vigorous physical activity, to provide them individualized rec-  
ommendations about sport intensity [2]. Exercise intensity may be expressed  
Athlete’s Heart  
Copyright © 2023 Elsevier Inc.  
All rights reserved.  
https://doi.org/10.1016/B978-0-323-95221-7.00003-3  
103  
104  
Athlete’s heart  
Fig. 1 Step-by-step approach to the cardiovascular evaluation of athletes.  
as a percentage of maximal aerobic capacity (VO2max),as a percentage of max-  
imal heart rate (HRmax), or as a percentage of an individual’s HR reserve  
(HRR) calculated according to the Karvonen formula.However,particularly  
in selected cases, exercise intensity should be better defined by ventilatory  
thresholds [3].Based on the results of a maximal exercise testing,preferentially  
with simultaneous measurement of respiratory gas exchange by CPET, the  
physician may draw out a personally tailored program,indicating the intensity,  
mode, type, and duration of exercise, that results in safe and effective for an  
healthy athlete,as well as for a young individual with a cardiovascular disorder.  
In athletes over 35years of age, exercise testing contributes to inves-  
tigating the presence of a silent ischemic cardiovascular disease through  
specific alterations in ST-segment andT-wave.However,it is less specific for  
myocardial ischemia than other functional tests, especially in asymptomatic  
and low-risk individuals. Therefore, a maximal exercise ECG test should  
be reserved for symptomatic athletes or those at high or very-high risk for  
coronary artery disease (CAD).According to the current guidelines for the  
chronic coronary syndrome,individuals with uninterpretable,borderline,or  
positive exercise tests should be further investigated [4].  
The exercise testing also permits assessing BP changes during exer-  
cise. An exaggerated BP response to exercise (systolic BP>200mmHg at  
a workload of 100W) should lead to start or optimize antihypertensive  
medical therapy and to perform a cardiologic evaluation, including ECG  
Multimodality imaging in athlete’s heart  
105  
Table 1 Athlete’s clinical and electrocardiographic features requiring further  
investigation.  
Clinical history  
Family history of sudden cardiac death/cardiomyopathies  
Palpitations  
Chest pain  
Syncope  
Physical examination  
Cardiac murmurs/abnormal cardiac sounds  
Marfanoid habitus  
12-Lead ECG  
T-wave inversiona  
ST-segment depression  
Pathologic Q-waves  
Complete LBBB  
Profound (QRS ≥140ms) nonspecific intraventricular conduction delay  
RBBB+left anterior hemiblockb  
Epsilon wave  
Ventricular preexcitation  
Long QTc (≥470ms in men, ≥480ms in women)  
Type 1 Brugada patternc  
Sinus bradycardia <30 beats/min  
Sinus pauses ≥3s  
First-degree AV block ≥400ms  
Mobitz type 2s-degree AV block  
Third-degree AV block  
Atrial tachyarrhythmias  
Ventricular arrhythmias  
PVCs ≥2 per 10s tracing  
AV, atrioventricular; ECG, electrocardiogram; LBBB, left bundle branch block; PVC, premature ven-  
tricular contraction; RBBB, right bundle branch block.  
aThe juvenile ECG pattern (T-wave inversion in leadsV1–V3) can be considered normal up to 16years  
of age; after that it warrants further assessment in Caucasian athletes.  
bIsolated RBBB does not require further investigation in asymptomatic athletes, with QRS duration  
<140ms, and without significant repolarization abnormalities.  
cType 2 Brugada ECG pattern does not require further evaluation unless there is history of syncope or  
relevant family history.  
Adapted from D’Andrea A, Sperlongano S, Russo V, D’Ascenzi F, Benfari G, Renon F, et al.The role  
of multimodality imaging in athlete’s heart diagnosis: current status and future directions. J Clin Med  
2021;10(21):5126.  
and echocardiography, even if the athlete is normotensive at rest since it  
predicts incident hypertension in athletes [5–8].  
A normal exercise testing is required for participation in recreational or  
competitive sports of asymptomatic individuals with heart valve disease [9].  
106  
Athlete’s heart  
Finally,exercise testing should be part of the routine assessment of patients  
with cardiomyopathies who wish to exercise to obtain information about  
functional capacity and risk stratification. In particular, exercise-induced  
symptoms or arrhythmias are markers of high risk and should result in  
more conservative training recommendations.The demonstration of ven-  
tricular arrhythmias with uncommon arrhythmias during exercise testing  
and/or during ambulatory ECG and monitoring including a training ses-  
sion should prompt further investigation and guide the most appropriate  
imaging tests to perform to exclude an underlying cardiovascular disorder  
[10,11].  
3 Exercise stress echocardiography  
Exercise stress echocardiography (ESE) is a reliable, safe, noninvasive im-  
aging testing, which provides a dynamic evaluation of cardiac function.  
Combined with clinical and electrocardiographic information, ESE helps  
detect cardiac abnormalities that may not occur at rest.  
The supine bicycle ergometer is preferred to the treadmill or upright  
bicycle since it allows images acquisition by echocardiography during ex-  
ercise.This trick is important, especially in athletes, who generally have a  
brisk recovery phase, with a fast return of heart rate and BP to baseline  
values [12].  
A typical indication of ESE is the detection of exercise-induced isch-  
emia in athletes with chest pain and/or ECG abnormalities that arouse  
suspicion of CAD or congenital coronary artery anomalies [13]. Maximal  
ESE should also be performed in asymptomatic individuals aged >35years  
with cardiovascular risk factors before engaging in high-intensity sports [9].  
The appearance of stress-induced hypokinesia or akinesia in ≥3 myocardial  
segments is an indication to perform invasive coronary angiography to con-  
firm the presence, extent, and severity of CAD.  
In endurance athletes with LV and/or RV dilatation and mildly reduced  
ejection fraction at rest,ESE can be used to assess contractile reserve during  
exercise.A significant improvement in contractility during physical exertion  
(≥10%–15% of the increase in LV ejection fraction at peak exercise) sug-  
gests a physiological cardiac remodeling;conversely,an absent or subnormal  
improvement suggests a pathological condition (e.g., dilated cardiomyopa-  
thy, LV noncompaction, and arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy) [14–18].  
Similarly,uncommon exercise-induced ventricular arrhythmias supports  
the hypothesis of underlying cardiac disease.  
Multimodality imaging in athlete’s heart  
107  
ESE allows also to monitor the intracardiac gradient. An LV outflow  
tract gradient >50mmHg during or immediately after exercise in athletes  
with borderline LV hypertrophy complaining symptoms (tendency to syn-  
cope and shortness of breath) may help diagnosing a hypertrophic cardio-  
myopathy [13,16].  
Finally,ESE may be useful in athletes with valvular heart disease.Indeed,  
it provides information about exercise tolerance, biventricular contractile  
reserve, changes in hemodynamics (LV filling pressure and pulmonary pres-  
sure), and valvular functional parameters (transvalvular gradients and regur-  
gitation entity) [16] (Fig. 2).  
Fig. 2 Dynamic diastolic dysfunction during stress echocardiography in a master ath-  
lete abusing steroids. Rest standard echocardiography (left panels) shows LV hyper-  
trophy with LA dilatation (A), and a mild diastolic dysfunction (E/Em 8) (B–C). During  
physical effort (right panels), B-lines (interstitial edema) appear at lung ultrasound (D)  
and a significant increase in E/Em (19 at peak effort) is observed (E, F). LV, left ventricle;  
LA, left atrium.  
108  
Athlete’s heart  
4 Cardiac magnetic resonance  
CMR is an extremely useful imaging method for the cardiovascular evalu-  
ation of athletes. It is a secondary diagnostic tool that helps to discriminate  
between physiology and pathology when echocardiography leaves doubts.  
CMR is the gold standard for defining biventricular volumes and mass,  
whose evaluation is made by the CMR cine imaging [19–21]. CMR has  
the incremental benefit of allowing tissue characterization by identifying  
myocardial inflammation and fibrosis through late gadolinium enhance-  
ment (LGE) andT1 mapping (Fig. 3).  
Gadolinium accumulates in areas of extracellular expansion due to fi-  
brosis,edema,or protein infiltration,and it can be detected in the late wash-  
out phase.The increased gadolinium concentration in areas of myocardial  
fibrosis causes T1-time shortening, appearing as bright signal intensity in  
T1-weighted CMR imaging.The distribution pattern of LGE can distin-  
guish between ischemic and nonischemic myocardial damage [22,23]. In  
the case of diffuse myocardial fibrosis, LGE imaging is less sensitive, and  
more recent T1 mapping techniques, including native T1 and extracellular  
volume (ECV) mapping, can be used as valuable tools for the differential  
diagnosis between athlete’s heart and cardiomyopathies [24–31].  
Compared to echocardiography, CMR is more sensitive in identi-  
fying cardiac abnormalities. However, it is less specific (higher burden of  
false-positive results), more expensive, less available, and therefore nonsuit-  
able as a first-line diagnostic tool [32].  
Fig. 3 Cardiac magnetic resonance of healthy athlete. Left ventricular wall thickness is  
increased (A), but no late gadolinium enhancement is detected (B).  
Multimodality imaging in athlete’s heart  
109  
As a consequence, CMR should be guided by clinical information to  
obtain the best sensitivity and specificity. CMR has also emerged as an im-  
portant complementary imaging modality, together with echocardiography,  
for diagnosing hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), the most common  
cause of SCD among young athletes [33,34]. It offers a superior visualiza-  
tion of LV apex and anterolateral free wall, and it allows to identify typical  
and atypical patterns of myocardial hypertrophy distribution (e.g., asym-  
metric septal hypertrophy, focal hypertrophy, isolated hypertrophy of LV  
apex, and isolated right ventricular hypertrophy) [35,36]. To differentiate  
between pathologic hypertrophy and physiologic remodeling, cardiac vol-  
umes and masses should always be compared to reference ranges deriving  
from CMR studies on healthy athletes, as it happens for echocardiography,  
and related to a number of factors including sport type, training hours per  
week, body surface area, age, gender, and ethnicity [21,37,38].The identifi-  
cation of myocardial fibrosis by CMR suggests HCM since fibrosis gener-  
ally occurs with cardiac remodeling due to pathology [39] (Fig. 4).  
Mid-wall myocardial fibrosis detected by LGE imaging is detected in  
approximately 60% of patients affected by HCM, and it is predominantly  
found in areas of maximum wall thickening. However, it can be present in  
nonhypertrophied segments too [40–42]. Notably, myocardial fibrosis can  
also be found in healthy athletes, particularly in a long-standing history of  
exercise training and endurance sports [31]. It generally involves less than  
3% of the myocardium, and it is typically situated in the right ventricular  
(RV) insertion points or the interventricular septum.The prognostic signif-  
icance of myocardial fibrosis in healthy athletes is still unknown.Conversely,  
Fig. 4 Cardiac magnetic resonance of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. In correspon-  
dence of a thickened interventricular septum (A), late gadolinium enhancement with  
patchy distribution is present (B, yellow arrow).  
110  
Athlete’s heart  
myocardial scarring in HCM showed to be associated with arrhythmias,  
cardiovascular death, and all-cause mortality [40,43]. Finally, T1 mapping  
techniques may be promising in identifying earlier stages of HCM by de-  
tecting low-grade, diffuse myocardial fibrosis, which precedes the develop-  
ment of overt LV hypertrophy [44,45].  
CMR plays a key role in diagnosing arrhythmogenic right ventricular  
cardiomyopathy (ARVC) and in the characterization of its phenotypic vari-  
ants.According to the 2010 revised Task Force criteria for ARVC, regional  
RV akinesia,dyskinesia,or dyssynchronous RV contraction,combined with  
indexed RV end-diastolic volume dilatation or RV ejection fraction re-  
duction, are considered criteria for ARVC diagnosis [46,47]. It should be  
noticed that RV dimensions alone are not reliable criteria to distinguish  
between athlete’s heart andARVC since athletes,particularly those involved  
in endurance sports, show a prominent RV remodeling, with RV dilatation  
and slightly reduced resting systolic function [48–50].A significantly higher  
dilatation of the RV than the LV, an RV ejection fraction ≤40%–45%, and  
regional wall abnormalities limited to the RV are more specific features for  
ARVC [51,52].Tissue characterization by CMR was not included in the  
2010 Task Force criteria because of limited experience, difficulty in the  
interpretation (the thin RV wall hampers LGE detection), and low speci-  
ficity (LV LGE can be found in other conditions, such as sarcoidosis, amy-  
loidosis, myocarditis, and dilated cardiomyopathy) [47,53]. However, recent  
studies showed that the best diagnostic accuracy is reached when regional  
wall motion and tissue characterization are considered together by CMR  
[54,55].Typical LGE detection suggests ARVC rather than physiologic RV  
remodeling and correlates with ventricular arrhythmias induced during the  
electrophysiological study [56]. Moreover, LGE can be found even in the  
forms of ARVC with early or predominant LV involvement, where the LV  
inferolateral wall may be the only affected region. In this setting, CMR  
increases diagnostic sensitivity,identifying the sub- and mid-myocardial scar  
of the LV infero-later wall even in the absence of systolic wall motion ab-  
normalities [54,57–59] (Fig. 5).  
In dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) and LV noncompaction (LVNC)  
diagnostic workup, CMR provides useful information about LV volumes  
and ejection fraction. LV dilatation alone cannot differentiate the physi-  
ologic cardiac remodeling from pathology, as athletes often show marked  
exercise-induced dilatation, accompanied by mildly reduced LV ejection  
fraction (45%–50%). A noncompacted to compacted LV myocardial layer  
ratio>2.3 in end-diastole by CMR suggests LVNC [60]. However, this  
Multimodality imaging in athlete’s heart  
111  
Fig. 5 Cardiac magnetic resonance of arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy with biventric-  
ular involvement. Late gadolinium enhancement deposition is indicated by black arrows.  
criterion may lead to LVNC overdiagnosis since a physiologic hypertrabec-  
ulation (in particular of the LV and RV apex) is common among athletes  
and is probably due to the increased chronic preload [60,61]. Features that  
favor cardiomyopathy over physiologic remodeling are the following: un-  
balanced LV dilatation (without concomitant dilatation of the other cardiac  
chambers), reduced resting stroke volume, LV diastolic dysfunction, wall  
motion abnormalities,absence of mild wall thickening,impaired global lon-  
gitudinal strain,lack of contractile reserve during stress echocardiography or  
CMR, and presence of LGE at CMR [62].  
CMR has become a vital tool even for the noninvasive evaluation of  
myocarditis. Myocarditis diagnosis can be made according to the 2018  
CMR-based updated Lake-Louise criteria [63]. Regional edema can be  
visualized during active inflammation using T2-weighted images and T2  
mapping [64]. Regional hyperemia and capillary leaks are assessed by  
contrast-enhanced T1-weighted images, acquired preadministration, and  
early postadministration of gadolinium [65].  
LGE images detect necrosis and fibrosis. LGE is typically patchy and  
involves the LV subepicardial layer with variable extension through the ven-  
tricular wall.The subendocardium is usually spared, allowing to distinguish  
this pattern from ischemic myocardial injury. LGE is generally localized in  
the inferolateral and, less frequently, anteroseptal segments, but its distribu-  
tion can also be multifocal or diffuse [66] (Fig. 6). Supportive criteria for  
myocarditis are regional or global LV systolic dysfunction and pericarditis.  
In the suspicion of a coronary artery anomaly (i.e., CAD), CMR may  
be useful for assessing wall motion abnormalities. This functional evalua-  
tion can be combined with the evaluation of LGE, whose subendocardial  
112  
Athlete’s heart  
Fig. 6 Cardiac magnetic resonance of myocarditis. Regional edema (A, yellow arrow) and  
subepicardial stripe of late gadolinium enhancement (B, white arrow) are detectable in  
the left ventricular lateral wall.  
distribution is specific for ischemic damage. Stress perfusion CMR may be  
performed to search exercise-induced myocardial ischemia, although other  
functional tests, including stress echocardiography and nuclear imaging, are  
usually preferred. Finally, CMR coronary angiography can be integrated  
into the standard CMR imaging when anomalous coronary artery origin  
is suspected, thanks to its ability in identifying coronary ostia and proximal  
course, despite computed tomography remaining the test of choice, given  
its ability to also characterize the course of the coronary arteries [67,68].  
5 Coronary computed tomography  
Coronary computed tomography (CCT) shows high accuracy in evaluating  
coronary atherosclerosis and coronary origin and course, including intra-  
mural [13].The assessment of coronary arteries by CCT is noninvasively  
performed and requires a very low radiation dose thanks to the latest gen-  
eration scanners [69].CAD is the main underlying cause of SCD in athletes  
>35years of age [70]. Therefore, depending on the local availability and  
expertise,CCT may be considered in athletes with symptoms suggestive for  
CAD and in older, asymptomatic athletes with risk factors for cardiovascu-  
lar disease and/or equivocal exercise stress test.The 2020 ESC guidelines on  
sports cardiology suggest CCT for cardiovascular assessment of asymptom-  
atic athletes over 35years of age at high or very high cardiovascular risk who  
want to engage in high- or very high-intensity exercise [9]. In this setting,  
Multimodality imaging in athlete’s heart  
113  
CCT allows identifying the presence, localization, and extent of coronary  
atherosclerosis by the detection of coronary artery calcium. Higher calcium  
scores were reported in endurance athletes compared to controls [71,72].  
These data suggest that the burden of atherosclerosis may be underesti-  
mated in older athletes with a healthy cardiovascular risk factor profile.As  
coronary calcification is an independent risk factor for all-cause mortality  
and cardiovascular events in the general population, an increased coronary  
plaque burden in the athlete should lead to performing functional imaging  
tests aiming at excluding exercise-induced myocardial ischemia. Contrast-  
enhanced CCT angiography (CCTA) may add information about high-  
risk plaque characterization and coronary fractional flow reserve (FFR)  
[73–75]. However, the diagnostic and prognostic role of these additional  
morphological and functional CT-derived parameters remains to be shown.  
In younger athletes (<35years),CCTA is the test of choice when the suspi-  
cion of coronary variants and anomalies is present (Figs. 7 and 8).  
When dilatation of aortic root or ascending aorta is suspected or con-  
firmed on echocardiography, at least one comprehensive aortic tomo-  
graphic assessment by CT angiography (or CMR,according to institutional  
preference and local availability and expertise) should be performed [62].  
Cardiac CT well visualizes pericardial thickening and calcification, and CT  
Fig. 7 Coronary computed tomography showing myocardial bridge of left anterior de-  
scending artery (black arrow).  
114  
Athlete’s heart  
Fig. 8 Coronary TC in a top-level athlete symptomatic for syncope. Right coronary ar-  
tery originates regularly from the right Valsalva sinus, whereas the circumflex artery,  
with smaller caliber, originates abnormally from the same Valsalva sinus (top left). The  
course of the circumflex artery to reach the left atrio-ventricular sulcus is retro-aortic  
(top right and bottom right). The left anterior descending artery originates directly from  
the left Valsalva sinus, with no left main coronary artery (bottom left and bottom right).  
(Courtesy of Giancarlo Messalli.)  
attenuation values may differentiate pericardial fluid contents [13]. CT’s as-  
sessment of LV volumes, mass, and ejection fraction has shown an excellent  
correlation with CMR [76]. CT is particularly useful for LV morphologic  
and functional evaluation in the case of suboptimal echocardiographic im-  
ages and when contraindications to CMR exist (albeit rare among athletes).  
Otherwise, this imaging modality is not recommended as a first-line tech-  
nique in young athletes due to ionizing radiation exposure.  
6 Cardiac nuclear imaging  
Myocardial perfusion imaging employing single-photon emission com-  
puted tomography (SPECT) or positron emission tomography (PET) can  
research exercise-induced ischemia and stratify the cardiovascular risk of  
athletes with suspected or known CAD, with the same indications as in  
the nonathlete population [4].According to the 2020 European guidelines  
on sports cardiology and exercise, nuclear imaging may be considered an  
Multimodality imaging in athlete’s heart  
115  
alternative or complementary exam to ESE or CCT for assessing asymp-  
tomatic individuals aged >35years with cardiovascular risk factors before  
engaging in high or very high-intensity sports [9].  
The accuracy of both PET and SPECT to detect CAD is excellent.  
However, PET may be preferred in balanced 3-vessel disease since it per-  
mits absolute quantification of myocardial blood flow. Conversely, SPECT  
can only provide semiquantitative values (normalized to the maximum  
value), failing to detect relative perfusion differences [77]. Moreover, even  
SPECT specificity in athlete’s setting has to be considered reduced since  
myocardial perfusion defects are common in young male athletes, and they  
are associated with LV hypertrophy and no wall motion abnormalities on  
echocardiography [78,79].As for CT,the indication to perform nuclear im-  
aging should be weighted to the risk of radiation exposure [80].  
7 Conclusion  
A broad spectrum of imaging modalities is available for the cardiovascular  
evaluation of athletes.The clinician should adopt a step-by-step approach  
to distinguish between physiologic, exercise-induced remodeling, and  
structural cardiac disease. This practical approach is based on the regular  
use of first-line screening tools (clinical history, physical examination, and  
ECG), possibly integrated by exercise testing and standard echocardiogra-  
phy.Third-line imaging modalities (e.g., ESE, CMR, CCT, etc.) should be  
selected when the previous evaluation is doubtful, as they provide valuable,  
incremental information on cardiac morphology and function, helping to  
discriminate between health and disease.

reference values for athletes and nonathletes corrected for body surface area, training  
hours/week and sex. Eur J Cardiovasc Prev Rehabil 2010;17(2):198–203.  
118  
Athlete’s heart  
[38] Luijkx T, Cramer MJ, Prakken NH, Buckens CF, Mosterd A, Rienks R, et al. Sport  
category is an important determinant of cardiac adaptation: an MRI study. Br J Sports  
Med 2012;46(16):1119–24.  
[39] Burchfield JS, Xie M, Hill JA. Pathological ventricular remodeling: mechanisms: part 1  
of 2. Circulation 2013;128(4):388–400.  
[40] Green JJ, Berger JS, Kramer CM, Salerno M. Prognostic value of late gadolinium en-  
hancement in clinical outcomes for hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. JACC Cardiovasc  
Imaging 2012;5(4):370–7.  
[41] Choudhury L, Mahrholdt H,Wagner A, Choi KM, Elliott MD, Klocke FJ, et al. My-  
ocardial scarring in asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic patients with hypertrophic  
cardiomyopathy. J Am Coll Cardiol 2002;40(12):2156–64.

ue of quantitative contrast-enhanced cardiovascular magnetic resonance for the evalu-

[46] Corrado D, van Tintelen PJ, McKenna WJ, Hauer RNW, Anastastakis A, Asima-

[48] La Gerche A, Heidbüchel H, Burns AT, Mooney DJ,Taylor AJ, Pfluger HB, et al. Dis-

nance imaging findings in patients meeting task force criteria for arrhythmogenic right

Multimodality imaging in athlete’s heart  
119

CHAPTER 6  
Gray zones in athlete’s heart  
Antonello D’Andreaa, Eduardo Bossoneb, Alessandro Seriob, and  
Gianluca Pontonec  
aDivision of Cardiology, Department ofTranslational Medical Sciences, University of Campania “Luigi  
Vanvitelli”, Monaldi Hospital, Naples, Italy  
bPublic Health Department, University of Naples “Federico II”, Naples, Italy  
cCardiovascular Imaging Department, Centro Cardiologico Monzino IRCCS, Milan, Italy  
1 Introduction  
One of the most debated issues on the athlete’s heart is the differential di-  
agnosis with cardiac pathological phenotypes.There are in fact several“gray  
zones”in which physiology and pathology overlap and therefore it becomes  
essential to relate the degree of cardio-circulatory adaptations of athletes  
to the biomechanical characteristics of the practiced sport, with particular  
reference to the hemodynamic cardiovascular commitment and arrhyth-  
mogenic risk [1] (Fig. 1). Many changes occur at the electrical, cellular, and  
structural level, all of which play a role in the physiological and functional  
adaptations to seemingly make the heart more efficient. Expected physio-  
logic changes can variate according to race, sport, gender, and ethnicity [2].  
Distinguishing athletic cardiac remodeling from cardiomyopathy is  
therefore very important and is a frequent medical dilemma for the sports  
doctors and cardiologists evaluating an athlete. It is therefore necessary to  
have a precise definition of the features of the athlete’s heart and stringent  
criteria to optimize the clinical management of these subjects, in order to  
be able to make a differential diagnosis with various pathologies including  
hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), left  
ventricular noncompaction (LVNC), and arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy  
(ACM).  
Transthoracic echocardiography represents one of the most important  
diagnostic tools in the evaluation of the athlete who is in this “diagnostic  
limbo,” to stratify the risk and to direct the clinician to any third-level  
tests (cardiac magnetic resonance and/or cardiac computed tomography) to  
complete the diagnostic process in cases where the echocardiogram is not  
completely clear [3].The use of advanced ultrasound methods such as tissue  
Athlete’s Heart  
Copyright © 2023 Elsevier Inc.  
All rights reserved.  
https://doi.org/10.1016/B978-0-323-95221-7.00002-1  
121  
122  
Athlete’s heart  
Fig. 1 Cardiovascular adaptations of heart chamber: atrium and ventricles dilatation,  
hypertrophy of left ventricle, hypertrabeculation of left ventricle. RA, right atrium;  
LA, left atrium; RV, right ventricle; LV, left ventricle.  
Doppler, two-dimensional strain, and “speckle tracking,” in addition to the  
classic echocardiographic assessments, represents an added value to com-  
plete a multiparametric assessment of these subjects,with the aim of helping  
to define more stringent diagnostic criteria for these dangerous gray zones.  
The purpose of this chapter is to analyze the different aspects of the  
athlete’s heart focusing on differential diagnosis with the ones of the main  
causes of sudden cardiac death in athletes.  
2 Left ventricular hypertrophy or hypertrophic  
cardiomyopathy?  
One of the most complex aspects in the evaluation of the athlete’s heart  
is the differential diagnosis with the pathological forms of left ventricular  
hypertrophy (LVH),such as HCM and hypertensive heart disease,consider-  
ing that concentric hypertrophy, usually symmetrically distributed and not  
exceeding 16mm,is reported in up to 10% of white athletes and up to 18%  
of black athletes [4]. Based on large cohort studies, the physiological upper  
limit for maximal end-diastolic wall thickness (EDWT) is 16mm, and thus  
athletes with a maximal EDWT >16mm may be considered to have patho-  
logical left ventricular hypertrophy [5,6].  
Gray zones in athlete’s heart  
123  
On the ECG, pathological LVH is typically characterized by the asso-  
ciation between increased QRS voltages (according to the Sokolow-Lyon  
criteria) and one or more nonvoltage criteria,such as left atrial enlargement,  
left axial deviation, prolongation of intrinsicoid deflection, alteration of the  
ST segment and T waves, pathological Q waves, and left bundle-branch  
block (LBBB) [7]. Inversion of theT wave in leadsV1-V2 is very common  
in adult athletes.These changes are more frequent in female athletes than in  
men (4.3% vs 1.4%) and even more prevalent in black athletes where the  
inversion of theT wave can also extend toV3 andV4 [8].In contrast,T wave  
inversion in lateral leads in any athletes should be thoroughly investigated as  
up to 50% maybe associated with cardiomyopathy [9,10].  
Many clinicians prefer cardiopulmonary exercise testing (CPET) to  
standard treadmill exercise testing to evaluate athletes as this test, allowing  
determination of oxygen consumption, is useful in differentiating an ath-  
lete’s heart from HCM. One study found that in this setting aVO2 max of  
<50mL/kg/min is pathological and mostly suggestive of HCM [11,12].  
However, it should be noted that some HCM patients are able to exercise  
at a high level and, therefore, may be able to achieve VO exceeding this  
threshold.  
In the absence of conditions inducing hypertrophy, HCM can be diag-  
nosed with a maximal end-diastolic wall thickness of ≥15mm in any zone  
of the left ventricle;less marked hypertrophy (13–14mm) can be diagnostic  
when present in relatives of a patient with HCM or along with a positive  
genetic test.For children,a threshold of Z score>2.5 may be useful to iden-  
tify early HCM in asymptomatic subjects with no family history, while for  
children with a positive family history or a positive genetic test, a threshold  
of Z score>2 could be sufficient for early diagnosis [13].  
The diagnosis of HCM in competitive athletes may be difficult when  
the extent of LV hypertrophy is mild and LV wall thickness is in the range  
of 13 to 16mm, which identifies the “gray zone” of overlap between the  
physiologic adaptations to training and mild phenotypic expression of the  
disease [14,15].  
Echocardiography is a sensitive diagnostic technique for the investiga-  
tion of LVH.The athlete’s heart morphology often presents intermediate  
characteristics between concentric and eccentric hypertrophy, in consid-  
eration of the large prevalence of mixed sports activities and the normal  
training protocols supported by athletes, in which is usually programmed a  
balanced activity of aerobic and anaerobic type [16].  
124  
Athlete’s heart  
HCM is characterized by a disparity between the magnitude of LVH  
and the left ventricular cavity size (often <45mm), while the athlete’s heart  
is characterized by a concomitant enlargement of the left ventricular cavity.  
For this reason, left ventricular cavity size is one of the most important dis-  
criminators between physiological LVH and HCM [17], although it must  
be considered that up to 10% of athletes with LVH exhibit normal left  
ventricular cavity size [18].  
With regard to cavity diameters, it has been shown that 55% of athletes  
have an end-diastolic diameter of the left ventricle (LV)<54mm,but about  
15% of endurance athletes with high cardiovascular commitment reach an  
end-diastolic diameter>60mm [5]. In general, it is advisable to index the  
end-diastolic diameter for the body surface area,which is often significantly  
increased in professional athletes of many sports [19].  
The increase of wall thickness in athletes shows a homogeneous sym-  
metrical distribution with a maximum difference of <2mm between the  
thickest and the thinnest LV segments. Conversely, HCM is predominantly  
characterized by asymmetric hypertrophy, usually located at the septum  
(>15mm in diastole; septal/posterior wall thickness ratio >1.3) but some-  
times also extended to the anterior and lateral walls [20–22].  
Relatively to the “gray zone” of LVH, with wall thicknesses between  
13 and 15mm, a more comprehensive assessment of the athlete is necessary,  
seeking the presence of family history of cardiomyopathy and/or sudden  
juvenile death (significant if ≤50years), cardiovascular symptoms, major  
electrocardiographic abnormalities, and eventually the presence of one or  
more mutations on genetic examination [7] or interstitial fibrosis, with the  
finding of late gadolinium enhancement (LGE) at cardiac magnetic reso-  
nance imaging [1].  
A peculiar feature of the athlete’s heart is the confirmation of absolute  
normality of left ventricle diastolic and systolic functional indices.The ejec-  
tion fraction (EF), fractional shortening (FS), and LV global longitudinal  
strain (GLS) are within normal ranges. Also stroke volume is normal or  
supernormal, and systolic peak velocity (s′) >9cm/s, while in pathological  
LVH (HCM or arterial hypertension) s′ is <9cm/s, with EF normal or in-  
creased in early stages and reduced in advanced stages [23].  
An athlete’s heart sometimes shows a transmitral flow pattern with a  
“supernormal” aspect (E/A ratio>2 with typical low A velocity), due to a  
large volume of proto-diastolic ventricular filling, and the contribution of  
end-diastole, in conditions of rest, is extremely reduced [24]. In contrast,  
there is a significant prevalence of transmitral flow with abnormal relaxation  
Gray zones in athlete’s heart  
125  
pattern (E/A ratio<1 and prolonged E velocity deceleration time) [25] in  
HCM and hypertensive heart disease, in whom diastolic dysfunction may  
be the first expression of the disease and may precede the development of  
LVH [21].  
Pulsed tissue Doppler shows an increased diastolic myocardial speed (e′)  
of the basal septum and lateral wall in athletes, contrary to what happens  
for HCM which is characterized by an e′ reduction in both the hypertro-  
phic septum and the normal thickness of lateral wall [26]. Some authors  
suggested that an e′ peak velocity threshold of <11.5cm/s on TDI can be  
useful to raise suspicion for pathological LVH [27].  
Athletes have no regional diastolic dysfunction (e′/a′<1), while this is  
evident in 25% of myocardial segments of HCM patients and in hyperten-  
sive patients [28].Accordingly, the E/e′ ratio is usually low in athletes but  
increased in HCM patients [29].  
Individuals with nonsevere HCM who play sports deserve special atten-  
tion because they may exhibit almost normal diastolic function [30].  
The athlete’s heart can be considered an interesting model of strain vari-  
ation at different loading conditions because there is a an LV adaptation  
at rest and a load dependency of strain measurement [30]. In particular, in  
athletes,mild impairment of GLS,lower apical radial strain,and lower twist-  
ing at rest than in sedentary controls have been observed, together with an  
increase of basal and middle radial and circumferential strain [31].Athletes  
had higher values for transverse, radial, and circumferential strains when  
compared with HCM [32]. In patients with hypertensive cardiomyopathy,  
DCM, and HCM, a severe reduction in global longitudinal strain with a  
significant prognostic impact was observed, showing a potential utility of  
this echocardiographic parameter in differentiating these pathological con-  
ditions from athlete’s heart [28,33,34].  
According to recent guidelines, references values of GLS for healthy  
persons oscillate around −20% [35,36], and a meta-analysis by Beaumont  
et al. reported that GLS values in athletes ranged from −16.5% to −23.3%,  
being even lower in endurance athletes [37].  
Speckle tracking echocardiography (STE) can also be used to evaluate  
left atrial function. D’Andrea et al. investigated whether left atrium (LA)  
mechanical dysfunction is present in patients with either physiological or  
pathological LVH using two-dimensional strain rate imaging:LA maximum  
volume was increased but similar between the two groups of patients with  
LVH. Peak systolic myocardial atrial strain was significantly impaired in pa-  
tients with pathological LVH compared with controls and athletes [38].  
126  
Athlete’s heart  
Thanks to the ability in identifying structural and functional abnormal-  
ities at an early stage, STE can improve the sensitivity and specificity  
for the differentiation between physiological adaptation to training and  
cardiomyopathies.  
Also coronary flow reserve could be used to differentiate between the  
athlete’s heart and HCM (Fig. 2).  
A summary of elements useful for differential diagnosis between HCM  
and athlete’s heart is reported inTable 1.  
However, due to poor acoustic windows and possible unfavorable hy-  
pertrophy location at the apex and lateral wall, transthoracic echocardiog-  
raphy does not always allow a differential diagnosis between an athlete’s  
heart and HCM [39].All competitive athletes with LV wall thickening that  
cannot be definitely attributed to the athlete’s heart and all cases with as-  
sociated marked ECG abnormalities and/or arrhythmias should undergo  
cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) [3,40,41].  
CMR plays a pivotal role in HCM diagnosis, phenotyping, and prog-  
nostication thanks to a clearer demonstration of the presence and the  
Fig. 2 Coronary flow reserve of LAD assessed by standard echocardiography in an en-  
durance athlete and in a hypertrophic cardiomyopathy patient (HCM). Note the signifi-  
cant increase of coronary diastolic velocities in the athlete, with CFR value >2, in contrast  
with the reduced vasodilatatory response in HCM. HCM, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.  
Gray zones in athlete’s heart  
127  
Table 1 Differential diagnostic elements between hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and  
athlete’s heart.

M: ≥15mm

history of SCD

hypertrophy after  
detraining

supernormala

or SCD

(20%–30%)

a E/A ratio>2 with typical low A velocity.  
HCM, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy; F, female; M, male; LV, left ventricle; SCD, sudden cardiac death;  
TDI, tissue Doppler imaging; CPET, cardiopulmonary exercise test; GLS, global longitudinal strain;  
GCS, global circumferential strain; ECG, electrocardiogram; PVC, premature ventricular contrac-  
tions; NSVT, nonsustained ventricular tachycardia.  
distribution of LV areas of focal hypertrophy compared to echocardiogra-  
phy; moreover, CMR represents the gold standard technique for left and  
right chambers volume quantification,EF estimation,and mostly allows tis-  
sue characterization by the means of precontrast images (T2-weighted im-  
aging and mapping techniques) and LGE imaging (Fig. 3). LGE is frequent  
in patients with HCM (up to 65% of cases) [42], while it is rare among  
young athletes [43]. Furthermore, CMR is capable to exclude several other  
causes of left ventricular hypertrophy, such as Anderson Fabry disease, am-  
yloidosis, and sarcoidosis [44,45].The presence of LGE shifts the diagnosis  
away from the athlete’s heart, in favor of HCM, particularly if LGE is lo-  
cated at the level of the more hypertrophied myocardium [46].  
Recently, the introduction of mapping techniques provided new fea-  
tures.A few promising studies showed the possibility to distinguishing initial  
stages of HCM from physiological athlete’s heart adaptations by measuring  
128  
Athlete’s heart  
Fig. 3 Patient 1: 27-year-old man, elite athlete (football), asymptomatic, known for ECG  
abnormalities (T wave inversion in anterior precordial leads). Panel A1: CMR cine mid  
short-axis view showing mild concentric LV hypertrophy (12–13 mm); Panel B1: native  
T1 mapping mid short-axis view showing normal precontrast T1 values; Panel C1: ECV  
mapping mid short-axis view showing normal ECV values; Panel D1: LGE mid short-axis  
view showing absence of myocardial fibrosis. Patient 2: 16-year-old man, athlete (bas-  
ketball), asymptomatic, known for ECG abnormalities (T wave inversion in anterior and  
lateral precordial leads). Panel A2: CMR cine mid short-axis view showing asymmetric LV  
hypertrophy at mid anterior septum and mid anterior wall (14mm; white arrow); Panel  
B2: native T1 mapping mid short-axis view showing mildly increased T1 values at mid  
anterior septum and the mid anterior wall (white arrow); Panel C2: ECV mapping mid  
short-axis view showing mildly increased ECV values at mid anterior septum and mid  
anterior wall (white arrow); Panel D2: LGE mid short-axis view showing mild intramyo-  
cardial enhancement at mid anterior septum and mid anterior wall (white arrow). While  
morphological features of patient 1 could be related to high-intensity training, asym-  
metric hypertrophy described in patient 2 is expression of HCM. CMR, cardiac magnetic  
resonance; ECV, extracellular volume fraction; LGE, late gadolinium enhancement.  
the extracellular volume fraction (ECV) [47].In HCM,extracellular matrix  
expansion and myocytes disorder lead to elevated ECV also at the initial  
stage [45,47], differently from athletes in which LV increased mass is due to  
prevalent contribution of intracellular expansion and myocytes hypertrophy,  
with subsequent relatively small ECV [48,49].  
Recent studies proposed a semiautomatic segmentation algorithm  
for measuring mass, volume, and function derived from CMR that en-  
ables more accurate and rapid measurements compared to conventional  
quantification [50,51]. Using this algorithm, papillary muscles and trabecu-  
lae are excluded from the blood pool. In a recent study, Csilla Czimbalmos  
et al. characterized gender-specific left ventricular hypertrophy including  
Gray zones in athlete’s heart  
129  
sport indices for highly trained Olympic athletes and HCM patients with  
conventional (CQ) and threshold-based (TQ) quantification methods.They  
found that elite healthy male athletes with very intensive and regular train-  
ing may reach the gray zone of hypertrophy in almost 50% of cases and that  
for sports index LVM/LVEDV TQ provides significantly better diagnostic  
accuracy than the conventional method even in subjects in the gray zone  
of hypertrophy [6].  
When the differential diagnosis still remains unresolved and in all  
controversial cases, the Italian cardiological protocols for sporting fitness  
(COCIS) [7] recommend re-evaluating the athlete after the interruption  
of sporting activity for at least 3months. In this way, the regression of septal  
hypertrophy is generally observed by about 15%–33%, while the simulta-  
neous reduction in the septum thickness (15%) and in the LV cavity size  
(7%) occurs after a longer period, with permanent interruption of all ac-  
tivities (from 1 to 13years) [52]. However, detraining also has limitations;in  
fact, in recent studies, it has been shown that cardiac remodeling following  
deconditioning is more evident in athletes who have practiced sports for  
fewer years than in athletes who have practiced sports for more years and is  
influenced by other variables such as the sport practiced and the body sur-  
face area. It is also very difficult to achieve complete detraining in an elite  
athlete, given the high number of training and competitions to which he is  
constantly subjected [20,53].The detection of a reduction in the thickness  
of left ventricular walls within normal limits (≤12mm) is a criterion that  
supports the diagnosis of the athlete’s heart.The reversibility criterion of  
LVH obviously does not apply to HCM, as well as to pathological LVH of  
the athlete who chronically abuses doping substances [54].  
3 Athlete’s heart or dilated cardiomyopathy?  
DCM is a myocardial disease characterized by ventricular dilatation and  
reduced systolic and diastolic function.Though rare, it is recognized as a  
possible cause of SCD in athletes [55].The usual echocardiographic pat-  
tern in patients with idiopathic DCM is characterized by diffuse LV dil-  
atation and hypokinesia; the mitral annulus also undergoes a progressive  
dilation that leads to functional mitral regurgitation [56]. Resistance exer-  
cise can lead to myocardial chambers dilatation, due to long-term volume  
and pressure overload; these conditions can overlap with DCM in partic-  
ular in its initial stage, with mildly depressed EF (≤55%) and enlarged LV  
(LVEDD˃58mm) [47].  
130  
Athlete’s heart  
Albergel et al. reported that the majority of elite cyclists had  
LVEDD>60mm [57] and limited data on CMR showed LV short-axis di-  
ameter>60mm in approximately 50% of elite male resistance athletes with  
a resting LVEF of 45%–50% in 28% of athletes and 40%–45% in 24% of ath-  
letes [58,59].As regard the differential diagnosis with the athlete’s heart,it is  
very important to consider the parameters of ventricular size and volumes  
indexed by body surface [60],and in cases of reduced FE at rest,evaluate LV  
systolic function by stress echocardiography (Table 2).  
Exercise stress echocardiography has the greatest discriminatory value in  
differentiating between gray-zone-athletes and asymptomatic patients with  
DCM [61].An increase in LV ejection fraction of at least 15% during exer-  
cise supports the diagnosis of athlete’s heart [1,7].  
In a recent study, Millar et al. have demonstrated that failure to increase  
LV ejection fraction ≥11% from baseline to peak exercise and inability to  
increase LV ejection fraction>63% at peak exercise during exercise stress  
echocardiography are suggestive of DCM with both high sensitivity (around  
80%) and specificity (˃90%) [61]. Strain analysis has also been proposed for  
the differential diagnosis between the athlete’s heart and DCM; however, a  
reduction of this value has been observed both in healthy athletes [62] and  
in patients with DCM [63]. Furthermore, strain appeared to have limited  
usefulness in investigating contractile function in healthy athletes with low  
left ventricular FE [2].  
Table 2 Differential diagnostic elements between dilated cardiomyopathy and  
athlete’s heart.  
DCM  
Athlete’s heart  
LV systolic function  
Diastolic dysfunction  
Reduced EF (<50%)  
Usually present  
Normal EF (˃55%)  
Usually absent (E/A>1)  
(E/A<1)  
Stress echocardiography  
Failure to increase LV  
ejection fraction ≥11%  
Usually altered  
Increased LV ejection  
fraction ≥15%  
Normal  
LV geometry  
Regional wall motion  
abnormalities  
Sometimes present  
Absent  
Biventricular  
enlargement  
Mitral regurgitation  
Family history of DCM, Often present  
heart failure, SCD  
Usually absent  
Often present  
Present  
Usually absent  
Usually absent  
DCM, dilated cardiomyopathy; LV, left ventricle; EF, ejection fraction; SCD, sudden cardiac death.  
Gray zones in athlete’s heart  
131  
From these conflicting data, it is evident the need of a better classifica-  
tion between physiological and pathological LV dilation in borderline cases  
by the use of CMR: it is able to provide, in addition to the precise and re-  
producible calculation of biventricular size and systolic function, important  
incremental information regarding tissue characterization and the presence  
of nonischemic fibrosis.  
LGE has been described in many patients with DCM as a typical intra-  
mural layer of septal fibrosis [64–66]. However, despite the high specificity,  
the absence of LGE does not exclude DCM.  
In a recent study, normal values of native T1 mapping and extracel-  
lular volume were found in athletes, whereas both values were elevated  
in patients with DCM [67].These data need to be confirmed in a larger  
population.  
Finally, the NT-pro BNP test can also be useful in the differential di-  
agnosis between dilated cardiomyopathy and athlete’s heart; patients with  
DCM usually show values>125pg/mL [61].  
4 Left ventricular noncompaction cardiomyopathy or  
adaptive hypertrabeculation?  
Left ventricle noncompaction (LVNC) is a rare form of cardiomyopathy,  
characterized by protruding trabeculae in the LV lumen, usually located at  
the apex and the lateral and inferior walls,associated with deep intertrabec-  
ular recesses, communicating with this cavity [68].  
Its prevalence in the general population is not well known, and the  
available epidemiological data should be considered with caution due to the  
obvious methodological limitations of the studies.  
The current diagnostic criteria are based on visualization and quan-  
tification of the two-layer structure (i.e., compacted and noncompacted)  
of the LV, with a ratio of noncompacted to compacted myocardial layer  
thickness>2.0 (measured at end-systole by transthoracic echocardiogra-  
phy) [69] or>2.3 (measured at end-diastole by CMR) [70].These criteria  
are purely morphological and appear scarcely specific for a diagnosis of  
LVNC, which must be supported by other elements of clinical signifi-  
cance, such as the presence of LV dysfunction, symptoms, and/or arrhyth-  
mias (Table 3).  
For these reasons,the diagnosis of LVNC may not be easy due to exten-  
sive clinical manifestation, incomplete knowledge of its characteristics, and  
difficult recognition by imaging.  
132  
Athlete’s heart  
Table 3 Differential diagnostic elements between left ventricle noncompaction and  
adaptive hypertrabeculation.  
Adaptive  
LVNC  
hypertrabeculation  
LV systolic function  
Diastolic function  
Sometimes reduced (EF Normal (EF >55%)  
<50%)  
Present (E/A<1)  
Normal (E/A>1) or  
supernormala  
Normal  
Thickness of compact  
layer  
Reduced (minimal  
thickness in systole  
usually <5mm)  
Present  
Ventricular arrhythmias  
Absent  
a E/A ratio>2 with typical low A velocity.  
LVNC, left ventricle noncompaction; LV, left ventricle.  
There is evidence that an increased myocardial trabeculation of the LV  
is quite frequent in some athletes [71] probably due to a chronic increase  
in cardiac preload in the context of isotonic physiology;a certain fact is the  
clear prevalence of LV hypertrabeculation in athletes of African-American  
origin compared to Caucasian athletes [72].  
The interest of physicians in this pathology is due to the occasional finding,  
during the medical-sports evaluation, of morphological images of ventricu-  
lar hyper trabeculation which require the differential diagnosis from LVNC.  
Physiologic hyper trabeculation is typically accompanied by preserved systolic  
function and normal or supernormal diastolic function.The finding of hypert  
rabeculation associated with a very thin compacted layer (<5mm) and/or a  
marked impairment of LV systolic function require a comprehensive evalua-  
tion for true noncompaction cardiomyopathy [73] (Fig. 4).  
Anyway, the currently used LVNC diagnostic criteria may lead to an  
overdiagnosis of this pathology [74].The study of Gati et al. is emblematic  
in this regard: the authors compared a cohort of 1146 athletes and 415  
sedentary healthy controls, with 75 patients already diagnosed with LVNC.  
It was seen that athletes had a high prevalence of increased left ventricular  
trabeculations compared to controls (18.3% vs 7.0%; P≤.0001), and about  
8% of athletes met the conventional criteria for echocardiographic diagno-  
sis. Only 0.9% of these, however, presented a further reduction in systolic  
function and marked changes in repolarization,suspected features for a pos-  
sible undiagnosed underlying heart disease [75].  
Another study of 2500 Olympic athletes found that 1.4% had excessive  
trabeculations suggestive of LVNC but when considering other features  
such as ECG abnormalities, arrhythmias, and other symptoms, only 0.1%  
were likely to have a true diagnosis of LVNC [71].  
Gray zones in athlete’s heart  
133  
Fig. 4 A 29year-old man, athlete (football), asymptomatic. On screening purpose, a  
transthoracic echocardiography was prescribed, showing normal LV size with trabec-  
ulation affecting several myocardial segments (Panel A, color Doppler showing blood  
within noncompacted myocardial layer). A CMR was then prescribed, showing biven-  
tricular size at upper reference limit, preserved biventricular ejection fraction, thinned  
compacted myocardial layer (4–5mm), and marked trabeculation affecting all mid and  
apical segment, and basal anterior and anterolateral walls (Panels B, C, D showing cine  
short-axis views at basal, mid, and apical level, respectively; Panel E: cine 2-chamber  
long-axis view; red arrows addressing trabeculae). Both Petersen and Jacquier criteria  
were reached. After gadolinium-based contrast injection, intramyocardial fibrosis (non-  
ischemic pattern) was described at the basal septal level (Panel F, blue arrow). In light of  
morphological features and nonischemic fibrosis, the diagnosis of LVNC was suggested.  
LV, left ventricle; CMR, cardiac magnetic resonance; LV, left ventricle; LVNC, left ventricle  
noncompaction.  
From such evidence derives,the consideration that this type of LV mor-  
phological abnormalities may be a consequence of the physiological in-  
crease in cardiac loading condition (increase in preload) of athletic training,  
and it has been hypothesized that LV trabeculations can be included in the  
list of changes of the athlete’s heart.  
Furthermore, it is encouraging that many studies in the literature eval-  
uating causes of SCD in athletes do not report cases of sudden deaths due  
to LVNC.  
Therefore, according to COCIS [7], the presence of isolated LV hy-  
pertrabeculation, in the absence of positive family history, symptoms,  
electrocardiographic abnormalities, or ventricular dysfunction, does not  
justify a diagnosis of LVNC. Finally, is clear the need for new stringent  
criteria for defining this pathology, to minimize the risk of overdiagno-  
sis and prevent the use of additional unnecessary and costly diagnostic  
methods.  
134  
Athlete’s heart  
5 Right ventricular physiological dilation or arrhythmogenic  
right ventricular cardiomyopathy?  
ACM is a genetically inherited heart muscle disease that is usually asymp-  
tomatic and the first clinical manifestation may be SCD [76].ACM is char-  
acterized by the loss of desmosomal integrity that leads to a myocardial  
fibrofatty replacement, predisposing to right ventricle (RV) enlargement  
and dysfunction and life-threatening arrhythmias [77]. Some studies have  
revealed that physical exercise can promote disease expression and progres-  
sion increasing the risk of SCD [78].  
ACM mainly affects the right ventricle, but there are also biventricular  
and left-dominant variants [79]. Knowledge of the diagnostic criteria is  
essential: diagnosis is based on structural, functional, and electrophysiolog-  
ical abnormalities, which integrate family history, electrocardiography, and  
cardiac imaging as outlined in the modified Task Force criteria proposed  
in 2010 and in the recent European Association of Cardiovascular Imaging  
(EACVI) recommendations [80,81].  
The athlete’s heart is not confined to the LV. Endurance exercise causes  
cardiac remodeling, involving both the LV and RV, while strength training  
appears to have minimal impact on the RV with the exception of strength  
athletes who abuse anabolic substances [82–84]. Echocardiography usually  
shows that the right ventricle participates in the enlargement process of  
the athlete’s heart with a parallel increase in the internal dimensions and  
thickness of the free wall [85]. Many studies showed that the athlete’s RV  
undergoes morphological, functional, and electrical changes that represent  
the adaptive response to the need for greater cardiac output during physical  
activity [86–88] (Table 4).  
The RV remodeling in the athlete is dynamic, as the chamber dimen-  
sions change parallel to the course of the competitive season and detraining  
causes a reduction in its size [89].  
Typical RV characteristics of the athlete’s heart can resemble those  
found in ACM: in ACM, the RV enlargement involves both RV inflow  
and outflow and may be associated with focal defects such as aneurysmal  
dilation or segmental dysfunction [30]; in athletes, the RV enlargement in-  
volves only the inflow tract, systolic function is typically normal [90], and  
the inferior vena cava is mildly dilated (range 17–25mm in 70% of cases)  
with normal inspiratory collapse (60%) [91]. In addition to morphological  
adaptation, the athlete may also encounter electrical changes to the RV. In  
fact, ECG finding of a delay in right intraventricular conduction, up to  
complete right bundle branch block (RBBB), is not uncommon; the latest  
Gray zones in athlete’s heart  
135  
Table 4 Differential diagnostic elements between athlete’s heart and arrhythmogenic  
cardiomyopathy.  
ACM  
Athlete’s heart  
RV dilatation  
Involves RVIT and  
RVOT RV wall  
bulging  
Mainly involving  
RVIT  
RV disfunction  
RV regionalWMA  
Reduced RV s′  
velocity<0.10cm/s  
RV longitudinal  
strain<20%  
Present  
Present  
Present  
Absent  
Absent  
Absent  
Present  
Absent  
RV/LV ratio  
>1  
<1  
Late enhancement at  
CMR  
RV and/or LV LGE  
with nonischemic  
distribution  
Absent  
Absent or only  
junctional  
Regression of RV  
dilatation after  
detraining  
Present  
ECG abnormalities  
QRS abnormalities,  
T wave inversion  
V1-V2-V3 ( V4-  
V5-V6 DII-DIII-  
aVF) low QRS  
voltage epsilon  
waves  
IRRBB or  
RBBB is not  
uncommon  
Ventricular arrhythmias  
Family history  
Present  
SCD or ARVC  
Absent  
Negative  
RV, right ventricle; RVIT, right ventricle inflow tract; RVOT, right ventricle outflow tract; LV, left  
ventricle; ACM, arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy; WMA, wall motion abnormalities; CMR, cardio-  
vascular magnetic resonance; LGE, late gadolinium enhancement; IRRBB, incomplete right bundle  
branch block; RBBB, right bundle branch block; SCD, sudden cardiac death.  
recommendations on the interpretation of the ECG in the athlete place  
the complete RBBB among the borderline anomalies that do not require  
further investigations if isolated [92]. In addition, the presence of ventricu-  
lar premature beats is frequently found, often starting from RV [93].These  
characteristics of the RV in the athlete can make a differential diagnosis  
with ARCV problematic, and a correct and early diagnosis under screening  
can be critical,challenging,and difficult to achieve.In fact,RV modification  
induced by training often overlaps withARVC major or minor criteria [94].  
For this reason,a recent EACVI joint position statement proposed that only  
major dimensional criteria indexed by BSA should be used to define RV  
136  
Athlete’s heart  
enlargement in athletes: specifically, RVOT >19mm/m2 in long axis, and/  
or >21mm/m2 in short axis, and/or RV end-diastolic volume on CMR  
>110mL/m2 in males and >100mL/m2 in females [14]. Other useful mea-  
sures that have shown specificity for ARVC include the ratio of RV inflow  
size (in apical view)/LV end-diastolic size (parasternal long axis view)>0.9  
or a ratio of RVEDV/LVEDV >1.2 on CMR [80]. In any case, the di-  
mensions of the RV alone are not sufficient criteria to distinguish between  
physiological and pathological dilation and must be associated with regional  
wall motion abnormalities [95]. In an attempt to simplify and standardize  
the assessment, an expert consensus proposed by Galderisi et al. advises, in  
the suspicion of ARVC in athletea, an echocardiographic evaluation as a  
first-level examination to identify any global and/or segmental RV systolic  
dysfunction,which absence would suggest an athlete’s heart,while the pres-  
ence would indicate the prescription of CMR imaging [95].Although the  
diagnostic criteria proposed by the Task Force in 2010 [95] only consider  
RV dilatation and wall motion abnormalities, recent data suggest the im-  
portance of tissue characterization with magnetic resonance imaging both  
for diagnostic and prognostic purposes [96].  
CMR may perform better than echocardiography and has the ability  
to identify the involvement of the left ventricle, a finding with an evident  
negative prognostic relevance: the subepicardial/intramyocardial extension  
of the fibro-adipose substitution can give reason to the normal LV size,  
function, and segmental wall motion as assessed with other imaging meth-  
ods, especially in the early stages of the disease (Fig. 5).  
Regarding the analysis of myocardial deformation, a slight reduction in  
RV free wall regional strain has been described in endurance athletes, as an  
expression of volumetric overload secondary to training, parallel to a slight  
increase in resting systolic pulmonary pressures and during effort [97].  
Several studies have also found a transient regional and global RV myo-  
cardial dysfunction after intense and prolonged physical effort (described  
by some authors as “Philippide syndrome,” the Athenian messenger who  
died suddenly after the extreme effort to bring the message of victory) [98].  
However,the RV contractile reserve during effort and at follow-up is normal,  
thus demonstrating the benign nature of this dysfunction in the athlete, af-  
fecting a chamber that is structurally inadequate to withstand acute overloads.  
Finally,D’Ascenzi et al.found that athletes practicing the largest number  
of hours per week of physical activity were those exhibiting the greatest  
degree of right ventricle remodeling, with the greatest values of RV end-  
diastolic volume and RV end-systolic volume [99].  
Gray zones in athlete’s heart  
137  
Fig. 5 A 25-year-old woman, athlete (swimming), asymptomatic but with nonsustained  
ventricular tachycardia during exercise ECG. Panel A: CMR cine basal short-axis view show-  
ing RV dilatation (RVEDV 115mL/m2, RVEF 48%). Panel B: cine 4-chamber long-axis view  
showing bulging at RV basal lateral wall (white arrow); Panel C: cine axial view at RVOT  
level showing systolic bulging (white arrow); Panel D, E, F: left anterior oblique (Panel D),  
lateral (Panel E), and septal (Panel F) unipolar electroanatomical mapping views showing  
low voltages area (red areas) at RVOT, basal lateral wall, and apex. Endomyocardial biopsy  
was performed, and features in keeping with inflammatory cardiomyopathy were found.  
Considering arrhythmic history, morphological, and functional abnormalities at CMR and  
matched abnormal voltages at electroanatomical mapping analysis, the diagnosis of  
ARVC was suggested. RV, right ventricle; RVOT, right ventricle outflow tract; ARVC, arrhyth-  
mogenic right ventricle cardiomyopathy; CMR, cardiovascular magnetic resonance.  
6 Conclusions  
In the differential diagnosis between the athlete’s heart and pathological  
conditions, it is required a multiparametric evaluation that includes various  
echocardiographic values as well as other instrumental, clinical, and anam-  
nestic data.The tissue Doppler and the two-dimensional deformation are  
both of fundamental importance for the cardiologist and the sports doctor  
in the study of the athlete, in order to distinguish between physiological  
adaptations and pathological conditions in the various sports disciplines.  
These “gray zones” are numerous (Table 5), and moreover, the costs related  
to nonoptimal management could be relevant, so the need for better diag-  
nostic criteria is reiterated.  
Table 5 Differential diagnosis between athlete’s heart and SCD-related cardiomyopathies.
