This page intentionally left blank  
CHAPTER 7  
Genetic testing in athletes  
Emanuele Mondaa, Michael Papadakisb, Silvia Castellettic,  
and Giuseppe Limongellia  
aInherited and Rare Cardiovascular Disease Unit, Department ofTranslational Medical Sciences, University  
of Campania “LuigiVanvitelli”, Naples, Italy  
bCardiology Clinical and Academic Group, St George’s, University of London, and St George’s University  
Hospitals NHS FoundationTrust, London, United Kingdom  
cSports Cardiology Unit, Cardiology Department, Istituto Auxologico Italiano IRCCS, Milan, Italy  
1 Introduction  
Sudden cardiac death (SCD) associated with athletic activity and sport is a  
rare but devastating event. Despite generally considered the healthiest indi-  
viduals of the society, athletes carry increased risk for SCD, as sports can act  
as a trigger for life-threatening event in the presence of an underlying car-  
diac disorder [1].The incidence of SCD in young individuals in the general  
population aged 1–35years ranges from 1.3 to 2.8 per 100.000 person-years  
[2–4], while in athletes it varies widely throughout the literature, ranging  
from 1:50,000 to 1:300,000 per year [5].  
Most of these events are caused by malignant arrhythmias, such as ven-  
tricular fibrillation or ventricular tachycardia degenerating into ventric-  
ular fibrillation, occurring in individual with inherited cardiac disorders.  
Competitive sports and high-intensity physical activity can act as a trigger  
for these events [6].Therefore, the identification of athletes affected by un-  
diagnosed inherited cardiac disease and the subsequent sport recommenda-  
tions are vital to minimize the risk of SCD [7].  
Several inherited cardiac disorders have been characterized as under-  
lying cause for SCD in athletes.The identification of these conditions in  
athletes should be followed by a tailored decision about sport eligibility.  
A cautious approach on advice for competitive sports and high-intensity  
physical activity has been historically used due to the unpredictable nature  
of SCD in this regard. Indeed, the level of risk associated with sport in pa-  
tients with inherited cardiac disease is well known only for some genetic  
cardiac disorders, and it is extremely difficult to stratify for each individual  
athlete.Moreover,risk stratification algorithms to prevent SCD in inherited  
cardiac disease are generally not applicable to athletes.  
Athlete’s Heart  
Copyright © 2023 Elsevier Inc.  
All rights reserved.  
https://doi.org/10.1016/B978-0-323-95221-7.00005-7  
147  
148  
Athlete’s heart  
In the recent years, there is an emerging trend in liberalizing eligibility  
for competitive athletes considered at relatively low risk for SCD [8,9]. It is  
crucial to involve the athlete in decision-making process to provide specific  
information of the disease and discuss the benefit and potential risk associ-  
ated with competitive sports and high-intensity physical activity. However,  
the shared decision-making process should be viewed in the context of  
different cultural and legal rules existing in each country.  
In this chapter, we will describe the inherited cardiac disorders associ-  
ated with increased risk for SCD in athletes, focusing on the role of genetic  
testing in these conditions.  
2 Genetic testing in athletes  
Genetic testing is a valuable tool for the diagnosis of several inherited car-  
diac disorder [10]. Genetic testing in athletes can be beneficial in terms of  
diagnosis, management, decisions relating to sport participations, and prog-  
nosis [11]. Moreover, the identification of disease-causing mutations allows  
for cascade screening in first-degree family members, due to the autosomal  
dominant pattern in most inherited cardiac disorders [12].  
The diagnostic yield of genetic testing is significantly different accord-  
ing to the clinical phenotype of the athlete. From a general point of view,  
the genetic testing in diagnosing inherited cardiac disorder is useful in in-  
dividuals with clear phenotypes, whose identification requires a compre-  
hensive clinical investigation, including family and medical history, physical  
examination, electrocardiography (ECG), echocardiography, exercise stress  
test, and other imaging test in specific cases [13], as discussed in the previ-  
ous chapters.The diagnostic yield of genetic testing in individual with clear  
phenotype ranges from 30% to 80% according to the underlying disease  
[14,15]. On the contrary, genetic testing is generally considered harmful  
when there is no clear phenotype.  
In the recent years,attention was posed on the diagnostic role of genetic  
testing in individual who exhibit an overlapping phenotype between in-  
herited cardiac disease and athletes’ heart [16,17]. In selected cases, when a  
comprehensive clinical evaluation is suspicious but fails to reach a definitive  
diagnosis of inherited cardiac disease, genetic testing may be considered,  
keeping in mind the specific diagnostic yield for each disease and that it can  
be even lower in athletes (10%–13%).  
Genetic testing in athletes  
149  
The benefit of genetic testing should always be weighted with potential  
harmful. Genetic testing panel should only include genes that have strong  
supporting evidence to cause the athletes’ clinical phenotype to minimize  
the identification of variant of uncertain significance (VUS) or allelic vari-  
ants associated with different clinical phenotype [10,18],which increase the  
difficulties inherent to the interpretation of genetic testing results.  
3 Inherited cardiac disorders in athletes  
Inherited cardiac disorders that may be responsible for increased risk of  
SCD in athletes can be categorized into two groups: cardiomyopathies and  
channelopathies.  
3.1 Cardiomyopathies  
Cardiomyopathies are defined as myocardial disorders in which the heart  
muscle is structurally and functionally abnormal, in absence of hyper-  
tension, coronary artery disease, congenital heart disease, valvular dis-  
ease, or other causes sufficient to cause the observed abnormality [19,20].  
Cardiomyopathies are classified into specific morphological and functional  
phenotype. The cardiomyopathies most associated with SCD in athletes  
are hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) and arrhythmogenic cardiomy-  
opathy (ACM), while a few data are available regarding the relative risks  
of competitive sports or high-intensity exercise in athletes with dilated  
cardiomyopathy (DCM), restrictive cardiomyopathy (RCM), or left ven-  
tricular noncompaction (LVNC). In this chapter, we will focus on HCM  
and ACM, since they represent the most common causes of SCD among  
athletes.  
3.1.1 Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy  
HCM is defined as a myocardial disease characterized by increased left ven-  
tricular wall thickness not solely explainable by abnormal loading condi-  
tions (i.e., hypertension, valvular heart disease, or congenital heart disease)  
[21,22]. It represents the most frequent cause of SCD among competitive  
athletes, up to one-third in US registries [23].  
HCM can be inherited as an autosomal dominant disorder with vari-  
able penetrance [24]. Among individuals with HCM, 30%–60% have an  
identifiable pathogenic or likely pathogenic variant in genes encoding  
for proteins of the cardiac sarcomere or sarcomere-related structures  
150  
Athlete’s heart  
[21,25].The most two common genes are those encoding for beta myo-  
sin heavy chain 7 (MYH7) and myosin-binding protein C3 (MYBPC3),  
which account for up to 70% of sarcomeric HCM. Other genes, such as  
troponin I3 cardiac type (TNNI3), troponin T2 cardiac type (TNNT2),  
myosin light chain 2 (MYL2), myosin light chain 3 (MYL3), tropomyosin  
1 (TPM1), and actin alpha cardiac muscle 1 (ACTC1), are detected in a  
small proportion of patients [26,27]. Moreover, different nonsarcomeric  
cardiac, metabolic, or systemic conditions are associated with left ven-  
tricular hypertrophy clinically mimicking sarcomeric HCM or athletes’  
heart. Examples of these conditions are lysosomal storage disorder caused  
by mutation in lysosomal-associated membrane protein 2 (LAMP2) gene  
(Danon disease) or galactosidases alpha GLA gene (Fabry disease), glyco-  
gen storage disorders, such as protein kinase AMP-activated noncatalytic  
subunit gamma 2 (PRKAG2) cardiomyopathy, or genetic syndrome, such  
as RASopathies [28–30].  
Clinical profiles of HCM are extremely variable [31] (Fig. 1).While  
the large majority of individual has a stable benign clinical profile,  
some patients develop an adverse clinical profile, including left ventric-  
ular outflow tract obstruction requiring invasive septal reduction in-  
tervention, increased SCD risk with consideration for an implantable  
cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD), atrial fibrillation with increased risk for  
embolic stroke, or systolic dysfunction requiring advanced heart failure  
therapies [31].  
Management of athletes with HCM includes treatment of symptoms,  
risk stratification for SCD, and family screening. Different risk stratification  
algorithms have been developed to identify individuals with high risk for  
SCD and recommendations vary between international societies [21,22].  
The American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association (ACC/  
AHA) guidelines identify as high-risk individuals those who present one  
or more of the following risk factors: family history of HCM-related SCD,  
unexplained syncope,massive left ventricular hypertrophy,extensive fibrosis  
at cardiac magnetic resonance, systolic dysfunction defined as left ventricu-  
lar ejection fraction less than 50%,nonsustained ventricular tachycardia,and  
the presence of an apical aneurism [22,32]. On the contrary, the European  
Society of Cardiology (ESC) recommends the use of HCM risk-SCD  
model, a multivariable logistic regression model that estimates SCD based  
on a formula that includes seven variables (i.e., family history of SCD, un-  
explained syncope,age,maximal left ventricular wall thickness,left atrial di-  
ameter, left ventricular outflow tract gradient, and nonsustained ventricular  
Clinical Profiles in HCM  
46%  
6%  
17%  
39%  
4%  
Sudden Death  
Uncomplicated  
Clinical Course  
Progressive  
Heart Failure  
(Obstructive)  
Atrial Fibrillation  
Advanced  
Heart Failure and  
End-Stage  
(Non-Obstructive)  
Fig. 1 Clinical profiles in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. HCM, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.  
152  
Athlete’s heart  
tachycardia). However, the diagnostic accuracy of these strategies has been  
derived from sedentary individuals and cannot be extrapolated to the he-  
modynamic stresses associated with competitive and high-intensity physical  
exercise.  
Overall, the current literature indicates that not all individuals with  
HCM are susceptible to life-threatening arrhythmias in exercise program.  
Thus, for most patients with HCM, participation in low-intensity com-  
petitive sport is reasonable. In contrast, the participation in high-intensity  
physical activity and competitive sports may be considered in individual  
with mild clinical expression of HCM and without low-risk profile, after  
a comprehensive evaluation and shared decision with expert provider  
who conveys that the risk for SCD may be increased, except for sports  
where occurrence of syncope may be associated with harm or death  
[8,22].  
Recently, attention was posed on possible benefits of the aerobic exer-  
cise in patients with HCM.The first randomized clinical trial of exercise  
in HCM patients was published in 2017 [33]. In this trial, participants were  
randomly assigned to 16weeks of moderate-intensity exercise training or  
usual activity.At 16weeks, there was a significant increase in the mean peak  
oxygen consumption among participants in the exercise training group.  
Moreover, no occurrence of sustained ventricular arrhythmias, sudden car-  
diac arrest, appropriate defibrillator shock, or death was observed. Future  
studies will be needed to evaluate the long-term outcomes and the po-  
tential influence on cardiac remodeling and disease progression related to  
exercise training.  
In athletes with HCM, a discussion about the role of genetic testing is  
considered the standard part of the clinical engagement, and an appropriate  
pre- and posttest genetic counseling should be performed [34].Genetic test-  
ing should be offered to athletes with clear phenotype of HCM. Moreover,  
it may be considered for the proper identification of borderline patients  
falling into the gray zone. Genetic testing plays an important role also in  
family screening and identification of nonsarcomeric cause of HCM.Several  
investigators have reported that patients with sarcomeric mutations exhibit  
greater disease burden compared with those without such mutations [35].  
Recently, an ESC Consensus Document suggested that genetic testing may  
be also considered in athletes with highly suspicious features (i.e., electro-  
cardiographic alteration, gray zone left wall thickness, and symptoms) [36].  
However, it is now well established that the identification of the specific  
Genetic testing in athletes  
153  
sarcomeric mutation do not reliably predict prognosis, clinical course, and  
outcome.  
3.1.2 Arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy  
ACM is a myocardial disease characterized histologically by fibrofatty  
replacement of the right and/or left ventricle and clinically by ventricu-  
lar arrhythmias, that can be life-threatening and culminate in SCD [37].  
ACM is one of the leading causes of SCD in young individuals and  
athletes under 35years of age in Italy [38] and in children and young  
adults in Australia and New Zealand [3]. SCD can be the first manifesta-  
tion of the disease, since the occurrence of arrhythmic events generally  
appear in the preclinical phase, when structural abnormalities are absent  
or minimal.  
Although it was originally considered as a heart muscle disease ex-  
clusively affecting the right ventricle, in the last decade, this concept  
has evolved in the current perspective of a cardiomyopathy that can  
involve both ventricles.ACM can be classified in arrhythmogenic right  
ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC) when there is a predominant in-  
volvement of the right ventricle, arrhythmogenic left ventricular car-  
diomyopathy (ALVC) when the involvement of the left ventricular  
exceed those of the right ventricle, and biventricular when it is bal-  
anced or parallel [39]. Thus, the original term ARVC has been pro-  
gressively replaced by the term “ACM” that better describes the entire  
spectrum of the disease.  
The genetic substrate of ACM reflects the predominant ventricular in-  
volvement.Pathogenic mutation in desmosomal genes,such as junction pla-  
koglobin (JUP), desmoplakin (DSP), desmoglein-2 (DSG2), desmocolin-2  
(DSC2), and plakiphilin-2 (PKP2), is responsible for disease development  
in more than 50% of individuals with ARVC [40]. In addition, there are  
disease-causing genes associated withARVC that do not encode for desmo-  
somal proteins but for binding proteins partners of desmosomal proteins or  
proteins whose function is disturbed due to desmosomal protein dysfunc-  
tion. In contrast, ALVC is predominantly caused by nondesmosomal mu-  
tations.The most common genes involved are those encoding for protein  
of the cytoskeleton, sarcomeric reticulum, sarcomere, ion channel, or mi-  
tochondria, for example, phospholamban (PLN), filamin C (FLNC), titin  
(TTN), lamin A/C (LMNA), and desmin (DES), which can be associated  
with other cardiomyopathy phenotypes, mostly DCM [41].  
154  
Athlete’s heart  
The diagnosis of ACM is based on multiparametric criteria proposed by  
expert consensus that consider genetic, clinical, electrophysiological, and an-  
atomical features of the disease [42] (Table 1). However, the original criteria  
were only focused on the right ventricular phenotype.They lacked sensitivity  
for the identification of expanding phenotype spectrum of ACM, which in-  
cludes prevalent-left variant,and did not incorporate LGE findings among the  
criteria.Thus, the 2020 international criteria have been developed and pro-  
posed to improve the diagnosis of ACM by the incorporation of tissue char-  
acterization findings and providing criteria for the diagnosis of ALVC [43,44].  
Table 1 2010 Revised Task Force Criteria for the diagnosis of arrhythmogenic right  
ventricular cardiomyopathy.  
1. Global or regional dysfunction and structural alterations  
Major By 2D echo:  
– Regional RV akinesia, dyskinesia, or aneurysm and 1 of the following  
(end diastole):  
– PLAX RVOT ≥32mm (corrected for body size [PLAX/BSA]  
≥19mm/m2)  
– PSAX RVOT ≥36mm (corrected for body size [PSAX/BSA]  
≥21mm/m2)  
– or fractional area change ≤33%  
By MRI:  
– Regional RV akinesia or dyskinesia or dyssynchronous RV  
contraction and 1 of the following:  
– Ratio of RV end-diastolic volume to BSA ≥110mL/m2 (male)  
or ≥100mL/m2 (female)  
– or RV ejection fraction ≤40%  
By RV angiography:  
– Regional RV akinesia, dyskinesia, or aneurysm  
Minor By 2D echo:  
– Regional RV akinesia or dyskinesia and 1 of the following (end  
diastole):  
– PLAX RVOT ≥29 to <32mm (corrected for body size [PLAX/BSA]  
≥16 to <19mm/m2)  
– PSAX RVOT ≥32 to <36mm (corrected for body size [PSAX/BSA]  
≥18 to <21mm/m2)  
– or fractional area change >33% to ≤40%  
By MRI:  
– Regional RV akinesia or dyskinesia or dyssynchronous RV  
contraction and 1 of the following:  
– Ratio of RV end-diastolic volume to BSA ≥100 to <110mL/m2  
(male) or ≥90 to <100mL/m2 (female)  
– or RV ejection fraction >40% to ≤45%  
Genetic testing in athletes  
155  
Table 1 2010 Revised Task Force Criteria for the diagnosis of arrhythmogenic right  
ventricular cardiomyopathy—cont’d  
2. Tissue characterization of wall  
Major Residual myocytes <60% by morphometric analysis (or <50% if  
estimated), with fibrous replacement of the RV free wall myocardium  
in ≥1 sample, with or without fatty replacement of tissue on  
endomyocardial biopsy  
Minor Residual myocytes 60% to 75% by morphometric analysis (or 50%  
to 65% if estimated), with fibrous replacement of the RV free wall  
myocardium in ≥1 sample, with or without fatty replacement of  
tissue on endomyocardial biopsy  
3. Repolarization abnormalities  
Major InvertedT waves in right precordial leads (V1,V2, andV3) or beyond  
in individuals >14years of age (in the absence of complete right  
bundle-branch block QRS ≥120ms)  
Minor – InvertedT waves in leadsV1 andV2 in individuals >14years of age  
(in the absence of complete right bundle-branch block)  
or inV4,V5, orV6  
– InvertedT waves in leadsV1,V2,V3, andV4 in individuals >14years  
of age in the presence of complete right bundle-branch block  
4. Depolarization/conduction abnormalities  
Major Epsilon wave (reproducible low-amplitude signals between end of QRS  
complex to onset of theT wave) in the right precordial leads  
(V1 toV3)  
Minor Late potentials by SAECG in ≥1 of 3 parameters in the absence of  
aQRS duration of ≥110ms on the standard ECG  
– Filtered QRS duration (fQRS) ≥114ms  
– Duration of terminal QRS <40V (low-amplitude signal duration)  
≥38ms  
– Root-mean-square voltage of terminal 40ms ≤20μV  
– Terminal activation duration of QRS ≥55ms measured from the  
nadir of the S wave to the end of the QRS, including R′, inV1,V2,  
orV3, in the absence of complete right bundle-branch block  
5. Arrhythmias  
Major Nonsustained or sustained ventricular tachycardia of left bundle branch  
morphology with superior axis (negative or indeterminate QRS in  
leads II, III, and aVF and positive in lead aVL)  
Minor – Nonsustained or sustained ventricular tachycardia of RV outflow  
configuration, left bundle-branch block morphology with inferior  
axis (positive QRS in leads II, III, and aVF and negative in lead aVL)  
or of unknown axis  
– >500 ventricular extrasystoles per 24h (Holter)  
Continued  
156  
Athlete’s heart  
Table 1 2010 Revised Task Force Criteria for the diagnosis of arrhythmogenic right  
ventricular cardiomyopathy—cont’d  
6. Family history  
Major – ARVC/D confirmed in a first-degree relative who meets current  
TaskForce criteria  
– ARVC/D confirmed pathologically at autopsy or surgery in a  
first-degree relative  
– Identification of a pathogenic mutation categorized as associated or  
probably associated with ARVC/D in the patient under evaluation  
Minor – History of ARVC/D in a first-degree relative in whom it is not  
possible or practical to determine whether the family member meets  
currentTask Force criteria  
– Premature sudden death (<35years of age) due to suspected  
ARVC/Din a first-degree relative  
– ARVC/D confirmed pathologically or by currentTask Force Criteria  
in second-degree relative  
Diagnostic terminology for ARVC criteria:  
– definite diagnosis: 2 major or 1 major and 2 minor criteria or 4 minor from  
different categories;  
– borderline diagnosis: 1 major and 1 minor or 3 minor criteria from different  
categories;  
– possible diagnosis: 1 major or 2 minor criteria from different categories.  
RV, right ventricle;RVOT, right ventricle outflow tract;ARVC, arrhythmogenic right ventricle cardio-  
myopathy; BSA, body surface area; MRI, magnetic resonance imaging; PLAX, parasternal long axis.  
Competitive activity is generally discouraged in individuals with ACM  
and even in carriers of disease-causing mutation [8]. It is well known that  
exercise has an important role in disease penetrance and arrhythmic risk. In  
desmosomal mutation carrier,the amount and intensity of exercise increases  
the phenotypic expression,ventricular arrhythmias,and the further develop-  
ment of heart failure [45,46].The right ventricle of individuals with desmo-  
somal mutation may be particularly vulnerable to pathological remodeling  
induced by exercise, which may facilitate myocyte uncoupling leading to  
inflammation, fibrosis, and adipocytosis. These pathological modifications  
are finally responsible for an increased risk of developing life-threatening  
arrhythmias and disease progression.  
Genetic testing in athletes with ACM should be considered only  
among individual who already fulfill the diagnostic criteria for defini-  
tive diagnosis to facilitate cascade screening of first-degree relatives.The  
diagnostic yield of genetic testing in individual with clear phenotype is  
Genetic testing in athletes  
157  
about 50% [47]. In athletes with a dilated left or right ventricle, genetic  
testing may be offered in presence of other features (i.e., arrhythmias of  
uncommon origin, symptoms) [36].Although some genes have been as-  
sociated with a worst phenotype (FLNC), genetic screening should not  
be used for risk stratification.  
3.2 Channelopathies  
Cardiac channelopathies are genetic diseases characterized by the dys-  
function of ion channel with a structurally and functionally normal heart.  
According to the registries,they account for up to 40% of the SCDs,also in  
athletes [48–50].The transmission is usually autosomal dominant, meaning  
that each children has a 50% chance to inherit the disorder. They usu-  
ally have incomplete penetrance and phenotypic expression variability.The  
main cardiac channelopathies are long QT syndrome (LQTS), Brugada  
syndrome (BrS), and catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycar-  
dia (CPVT). Other channelopathies include short QT syndrome (SQTS)  
and early repolarization syndrome (ER).  
3.2.1 Long QT syndrome  
LQTS is an inherited cardiac disorder characterized by QT prolonga-  
tion and repolarization abnormalities on basal ECG and increased risk  
for life-threatening events, usually stress induced. The manifestation of  
the disease is usually a syncope due to a typical polymorphic ventricular  
tachycardia, such as the Torsade-de-Pointes (TdP), which may degenerate  
in ventricular fibrillation, accounting for a mortality rate of 5% per year  
among untreated symptomatic patients [51].  
The QT corrected for heart rate (QTc) is defined as prolonged when  
it measures >440ms in men and >460ms in women after puberty [52].  
However, athletes may display a more prolonged QTc; therefore, normal  
values are considered up to 460ms and up to 480ms in male and female  
athletes, respectively.  
However, it has been demonstrated that between 10% and 36% of  
patients, according to genotype, may display a normal QTc (“silent mu-  
tation carriers”) [53,54].Therefore, besides the QTc value, it is important  
to scrutinize the ECG since affected patients may also present T waves  
abnormalities, such as notched, diphasic, or late-peakedT waves [55].The  
correct diagnosis is important in mutation carriers as it has been demon-  
strated that patients with normal QT but genotype positive may have as  
much as a 10% risk of experiencing a major cardiac event by age 40years  
158  
Athlete’s heart  
[56].They have a 4% probability of cardiac arrest,which is 10 times higher  
of unaffected people, although lower of those with a prolonged QT in-  
terval [56].  
LQTS is commonly inherited as an autosomal dominant disorder  
[57]. Since the first description, 17 genes have been linked to the disease.  
Almost 90% of patients with a positive genotype carry a mutation in one  
of the three main genes: KCNQ1 (LQTS Type 1), KCNH2 (LQTS Type  
2), SCN5A (LQTSType 3) [57].A few patients (15%–20%) has a negative  
genetic testing despite a definite clinical diagnosis (genotype-negative).  
Genotyping is important as genotype-phenotype correlations exist.  
LQT1 patients usually present with broad-basedT waves and arrhythmic  
events during stress or exercise, with swimming representing the 33%  
of cases [58]. LQT2 patients commonly display diphasic or notched T  
waves and arrhythmic events during emotional stress, with sudden au-  
ditory stimuli representing the 63% of cases [59]. LQT3 patients usually  
have late-onset peaked T waves and arrhythmic events while at rest or  
asleep [58]. Nevertheless, also the minor genes are important, as some of  
them are associated with a more arrhythmic phenotype [60].Also, those  
patients with multiple mutations in the LQTS genes (about 5%–10%)  
usually present a more severe phenotype compared to those patients with  
a single mutation [61].  
It is therefore clear that, once the clinical diagnosis is established, the  
genetic characterization is important, especially in an athlete, as it carries  
important sports recommendation implications [7].  
Considering the characteristic features of LQTS, a clinical diagnos-  
tic score based on electrocardiographic characteristics, personal, and  
familial history has been developed, the so-called Schwartz score [62]  
(Table 2).  
Typical features on ECG are: QTc prolongation; peculiar T wave  
morphologies;T wave alternans; 2:1 functional atrio-ventricular blocks.  
The Bazett’s formula represents the most widely recognized formula to  
correct the QT. Exercise stress testing is a useful investigation for the  
clinical diagnosis. A failure in QT adaptation during exercise is usu-  
ally observed in LQT1, but also in LQT2 patients, and a QTc ≥480ms  
at the 4th minute of the recovery phase is listed among the Schwartz  
score criteria [62,63].Therefore, it is important during a preparticipation  
screening to record the ECG during exercise testing at least until the 4th  
minute of recovery. Moreover, the degree of heart rate reduction during  
the 1st minute of recovery may provide prognostic information in LQT1  
Genetic testing in athletes  
159  
Table 2 Long QT syndrome diagnostic criteria.

SCORE: ≤1 point: low probability of LQTS; 1.5 to 3 points: intermediate probability of LQTS;  
≥3.5 points high probability.  
LQTS, long QT syndrome.  
a In the absence of medications or disorders known to affect these electrocardiographic features.  
b QTc calculate by Bazett’s formula.  
c Resting heart rate below the second percentile for age.  
d The same family member cannot be counted in A and B.  
patients, who are those experiencing events mainly during exercise [64].  
A 12-lead 24-h Holter monitoring may increase the diagnostic sensi-  
tivity, as it allows the identification of sudden sinus pauses, changes in  
QTc during the night-time, the maximum QTc and of repolarization  
abnormalities [65].  
According to guidelines, clinical diagnosis can be performed in the  
presence of an unequivocally pathogenic mutation and/or in the pres-  
ence of a QTc≥ 500ms in repeated ECGs, or when the patient has a  
Schwartz score of ≥3.5 points [52] (Table 2). Secondary causes of QT  
prolongation (i.e., drugs, hypokalaemia, and hormonal changes) need to  
be excluded.  
160  
Athlete’s heart  
However, in athletes, the diagnosis may be even more challenging,  
especially in those presenting borderline QTc values with a negative  
personal and/or familial history. Recently, it has been observed the  
existence of an exercise-induced LQTS phenotype. Patients with this  
phenotype are usually asymptomatic and with unremarkable familial  
history, negative genetic testing, and their QTc usually normalizes af-  
ter a period of detraining. Therefore, in athletes, who already display  
a slightly prolonged QTc, diagnosis may be difficult; nevertheless, the  
correct diagnosis is crucial in athletes, as arrhythmic events present  
during exercise and effective treatments are available. The first-line  
therapy is beta-blockers, nadolol, and propranolol, which can reduce  
the probability of events greatly, especially in LQT1 patients [66]. Other  
therapeutic approaches include left cardiac sympathetic denervation  
(LCSD), usually performed in symptomatic patients despite a targeted  
beta-blocker therapy or not tolerant to the therapy, and the ICD im-  
plantation, indicated in patients with a previous cardiac arrest or symp-  
tomatic despite beta-blockers and LCSD [65]. All patients should also  
be instructed in avoiding QT-prolonging drugs and hypokalemia [65].  
Also, energetic drinks are contraindicated. Moreover, according to the  
sports cardiology guidelines, LQT1 patients should avoid competitive  
sports, especially swimming [7].  
Considering all the diagnostic, prognostic, therapeutic, and sport  
recommendation implications of genetic testing in LQTS, genetic test-  
ing in athletes should be offered in all cases with a clinical diagnosis of  
disease, a high pretest probability of disease. It may also be considered  
in athletes with borderline LQTS regardless of personal and familial  
history.  
3.2.2 Brugada syndrome  
Brugada syndrome (BrS) is a genetic disorder characterized by a coved-  
type ST elevation in the right precordial ECG leads and an increased risk  
of SCD.  
Diagnosis is very challenging as the typical ECG pattern is not always  
present on the surface ECG, even in affected subjects.The heart is struc-  
turally normal; however, recent studies have shown the presence of mi-  
nor structural abnormalities [67] with the identification of genetic variants  
linked with ACM, leading to the concept of BrS as part of the spectrum of  
the disease [68].  
Genetic testing in athletes  
161  
The main gene involved in the disease is SCN5A, encoding for the  
voltage-gated Nav1.5 sodium channel, which is responsible for 20%–30%  
of the genotype-positive patients [69].Other genes implicated in the disease  
have been identified in only a maximum 5% of the cases [70]. Considered  
for years as an autosomal dominant monogenetic disease, in the last years, a  
few studies have suggested that the phenotype may be modulated by com-  
mon genetic variants [71,72].  
The manifestation of the disease is variable, from no symptoms to sud-  
den cardiac arrest. Usually, symptoms occur more often in men at a mean  
age of 40years old [73]; however, arrhythmic events in children have been  
described [74,75]. Other manifestations of the disease may also include  
supraventricular arrhythmias (such as atrial fibrillation, Wolff-Parkinson-  
Whyte syndrome, atrioventricular nodal re-entrant tachycardia) occurring  
in around 20% of cases [76–78],conduction delays (such as prolonged atrio-  
ventricular conduction, atrial standstill, prolonged sinus node recovery and  
sinoatrial conduction times, slowed atrial conduction) [70,79,80].  
The presence of a diagnostic pattern on the basal ECG and arrhythmic  
events may be triggered by fever [73,81], sodium-channel blockers intake,  
increased vagal tone conditions, such as at rest or while asleep, after high  
alcohol intake and/or heavy meals and during the recovery phase of the  
exercise [82–85].Thus, it has been thought for years that athletes may be  
to an increased risk of events. However, during the last years, a more open  
approach has been established for sports recommendation in affected pa-  
tients [7].  
The diagnosis is made in the presence of a coved-type ST elevation in  
at least one right precordial lead (V1 andV2) (Type-1 ECG), in a standard  
position or in a high intercostal space (V1 andV2 placed in the third or sec-  
ond intercostal space) [15,86]. Other ECG patterns considered suspicious  
are the type-2 and type-3 ECGs.The type-2 (“saddle-back type”) is charac-  
terized by an ST-segment elevation ≥2mm, in ≥1 right precordial lead (V1  
toV3),followed by a convex ST and a positiveT-waves inV2,the type-3 has  
either a saddle-back or a coved-type appearance but the ST-segment ele-  
vation is less than 1mm. It is important to underlie that type-2 and type-3  
ECGs are not diagnostic ECGs. If they are detected, a 12-lead 24-h Holter  
monitoring and eventually a drug challenge test with a sodium-channel  
blocking agent should be performed. Indeed, the ECG may change greatly  
during the 24h, and the diagnostic pattern may appear during rest or sleep,  
a 12-lead 24-h monitoring, performed placing the leads also in the higher  
162  
Athlete’s heart  
intercostal spaces,is indicated to detect a diagnostic pattern during the night  
[87]. However, the absence of a diagnostic pattern during the 12-lead 24-h  
monitoring does not rule out the disease. In this case, a drug challenge test  
with a sodium-channel blocking agent, such as ajmaline, flecainide, and  
procainamide, should be performed [15,88]. Only the conversion of the  
ECG into type-1 pattern is considered diagnostic for the disease.The ex-  
ercise stress testing may be able to unmask a diagnostic pattern during the  
recovery phase, as for the increased vagal tone [84,89]. Several conditions  
may mimic the BrS and should be excluded.Among them, acute myocar-  
dial ischemia or infarction, Prinzmetal angina, right ventricular ischemia,  
acute pulmonary embolism, mechanical compression of the right ventricle  
outflow tract,and others more.However,the most important differential di-  
agnosis in an athlete is with the ST-segment elevation typically observed in  
the most well trained, characterized by an upslope rather than a downslope.  
Several criteria have been suggested for the differential diagnosis; however,  
none of them rule out the disease [90,91].  
The presence of a type-1 ECG present without triggering conditions  
(spontaneous pattern) and symptoms prior the diagnosis predicts a worse  
outcome, and an ICD should be considered in symptomatic patients (e.g.,  
those experiencing syncope).Asymptomatic patients without a spontaneous  
pattern are considered at low risk of events and for them are recommended  
lifestyle changes [92]. However, there is no consensus on the risk stratifica-  
tion of asymptomatic patients with a type-1 ECG present without a sponta-  
neous type-1 ECG pattern. Different clinical variables have been associated  
with a prognostic significance, including the presence of a SCN5A muta-  
tion [93].However,they are mainly derived from small observational studies  
and have not been validated.Recently,a risk score based on four risk factors  
has been proposed [94].The use of the electrophysiological study has been  
debated for several years, and the current guidelines neither encourage nor  
discourage its use for risk stratification [87,89,93].Therapy includes lifestyle  
changes and ICD or drugs in selected patients [86].  
Considering the low yield of genetic testing (up to 30%), it should  
be performed in all patients with a definitive diagnosis and for cascade  
screening.  
3.2.3 Catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia  
Catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (CPVT) is another  
inherited cardiac disorder characterized by adrenergic-induced arrhythmias  
with a normal structural heart and basal ECG.  
Genetic testing in athletes  
163  
The disease is caused by an alteration of the calcium handling due to the  
presence of a gene mutation that usually leads to an increased calcium leak  
from the sarcoplasmic reticulum and electrical instability. The main gene  
involved is ryanodine receptor 2,RyR2,encoding for the cardiac ryanodine  
receptor,responsible of 60% of cases and inherited with an autosomal dom-  
inant trait. Other genes involved with an autosomal dominant trait include  
the potassium inward rectifying channel subfamily J member 2, KCNJ2  
(less than 5% of cases) [95] and calmodulin 1–3,CALM1–3 (less than 1% of  
cases) [96]. More rarely, the disease is transmitted in an autosomal recessive  
form, which may involve the cardiac calsequestrin, CASQ2, gene (5% of  
cases) or the triadin, TRDN, gene (1% of cases).  
Syncope and cardiac arrest triggered by exercise or acute emotion are  
the main manifestations.They usually occur early in life (childhood or ad-  
olescence) [97–99]. SCD represents the first manifestation in up to 50% of  
untreated patients before the age of 20 [15,97].  
The typical arrhythmia is a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia, with a  
beat-to-beat alternating QRS axis rotating of 180degrees.  
The diagnosis is performed clinically with exercise stress testing.Usually  
at 100–110bpm, it shows the appearance of ventricular arrhythmias, which  
increase in number and complexity with the increasing heart rate. Runs of  
nonsustained ventricular arrhythmias may appear and a sustained ventric-  
ular tachycardia may occur if the test is not interrupted.When the exer-  
cise is stopped, the arrhythmias progressively disappear. Arrhythmias may  
originate from both the right or left ventricle and the QRS axis alternans  
may not always be present. Some patients may also show isolated atrial  
premature beats, supraventricular tachycardia, or runs of atrial fibrillation  
during exercise [100,101]. The pattern of arrhythmias onset is highly re-  
producible without therapy.As an alternative test to the exercise stress test-  
ing, isoproterenol infusion may be used; however, its sensitivity is not well  
established [102]. In those patients with symptoms during emotional stress,  
in young children and infants, a 12-lead 24-h Holter monitoring may be  
useful for the diagnosis.  
The differential diagnosis includes Andersen-Tawill syndrome and  
ACM. In the first one, however, the ECG typically shows prominent U  
waves, and the arrhythmias are not always adrenergic induced. Moreover,  
patients may have periodic paralysis and dysmorphisms [95]. In the second  
case,the arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy,usually the patient presents struc-  
tural abnormalities and the arrhythmias,do not show a reproducible pattern  
during exercise stress testing [44].  
Isolated LVH  
Isolated LV dilatation  
Isolated RV dilation  
Isolated QT prolongation  
Isolated monomorphic PVC  
LVH + additional features  
LV + additional features  
RV dilation + additional features  
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy  
Dilated cardiomyopathy  
Arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy  
Long QT syndrome  
QTc>480ms +/- additional features  
NSVT or polymorphic PVC +/- additional features  
Catecholaminergic ventricular tachycardia  
Pre-test probability  
Intermediate  
High  
Low  
Genetic testing  
is not recommended  
Genetic testing  
is recommended  
Genetic testing  
may be considered  
Fig. 2 Recommendations for genetic testing in athletes. LV, left ventricle; LVH, left ventricular hypertrophy; NSVT, nonsustained ventric-  
ular tachycardia; PVC, premature ventricular contraction; RV, right ventricle.  
Genetic testing in athletes  
165  
The persistence of arrhythmias despite an optimal therapy and the his-  
tory of cardiac arrest before diagnosis are associated with a worst prog-  
nosis; however, there is no risk score available. Nevertheless, the disease is  
well controlled with lifestyle changes and beta-blockers,nadolol,most of all  
therapy [15,86,103].The association with flecainide has been shown to be  
effective in controlling arrhythmias [104].Left sympathetic cardiac denerva-  
tion with an implantable defibrillator should be considered in symptomatic  
patients on therapy [15,86,105].  
Considering the association of arrhythmias with exercise and the  
availability of effective therapy, it is undoubted that the correct diagno-  
sis in an athlete cannot be missed. As such, a genetic testing should be  
performed in every athlete with a highly suspicious of disease or with an  
established diagnosis. It may also be considered in athletes with arrhyth-  
mias during exercise not in a typical pattern in the presence of personal  
or familial history.  
4 Conclusion  
Genetic testing is an increasingly available tool in the diagnostic evaluation  
of athletes, as a second-level tool to facilitate diagnosis and guide manage-  
ment of underlying inherited cardiac disorders.Since the diagnostic yield of  
genetic testing is significantly different according to the clinical phenotype  
of the athlete, it is crucial that physicians involved in the athlete’s care have  
a solid understanding of the indications,strengths,and limitations of genetic  
testing (Fig. 2).
